ExplntnTxt: AID AND GRANTS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S ESSEX COUNTY COLLEGE ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION AND FEES. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS SUBJECT TO REVISION BASED ON AVAILABILITY, CHANGES IN FAMILY CONTRIBUTION AND/OR CREDIT LOAD. ELIGIBILITY FOR STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS BASED ON GENERAL ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS OF TITLE IV STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS, OR STATE OF NEW JERSEY GENERAL ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. BOTH FEDERAL AND STATE AID GENERAL ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS INCLUDE THE FILING OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA), EXCEPT IN THE CASE OF NJ "DREAMERS", WHO ARE REQUIRED TO FILE THE NJ ALTERNATIVE FINANCIAL AID APPLICATION. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE REVIEWS APPLICATIONS, REVIEWS NEED ANALYSIS DATA AND DOCUMENTATION, PERFORMS NEED ANALYSIS, PERFORMS VERIFICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID PROGRAMS, PACKAGES STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, AND CERTIFIES PRIVATE EDUCATION LOANS.

THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS BY AWARDING THOSE FUNDS ONLY TO ENROLLED STUDENTS TO BE USED FOR STUDENTS' TUITION AND FEES. FEDERAL AWARDS ARE SUBJECT TO AN AUDIT BY AN INDEPENDENT AUDITOR ON AN ANNUAL BASIS PURSUANT TO OMB CIRCULAR A-133.

THESE FUNDS REPRESENT FINANCIAL AID ISSUED TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS, TUITION DISCOUNTS, AND INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FROM FRANCISCAN UNIVERSITY ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE THEY MEET THE ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS OR OTHER CRITERIA ASSOCIATED WITH THE RESPECTIVE AWARD. GRANTS FOR SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS AND STUDENT LOANS ARE MADE UPON FINANCIAL NEED AND THE ACADEMIC PROMISE OF STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FINANCIAL AID. ALL RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNT OF GRANTS OR ASSISTANCE MADE TO STUDENTS.

ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE OFFERED BASED ON MANUAL AND/OR ELECTRONIC VERIFICATION OF ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA. THE SYSTEM DISBURSEMENT OF THE SCHOLARSHIPS TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT OCCURS ONLY AFTER GLOBAL AND ITEM SPECIFIC DISBURSEMENT ELIGIBILITY RULES ARE MET. UPON DISBURSEMENT, PAYMENT ALLOCATION RULES IN THE SYSTEM ALLOCATE THE SCHOLARSHIPS TO APPROPRIATE PREDEFINED CHARGES. AFTERWARDS DISBURSEMENT AUDITS ARE COMPLETED AT VARIOUS TIME INTERVALS TO DETERMINE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: subrecipient grants: Vanderbilt University maintains a formal policy defining its procedures for monitoring the use of sponsored funds by subrecipients who are performing a portion of a sponsored project externally awarded to Vanderbilt. The policy provides guidance to ensure that subrecipients conduct their portions of sponsored projects in compliance with laws, regulations, terms and conditions of awards and subawards, and that reimbursed costs incurred by subrecipients are allowed. The policy addresses the roles and responsibilities of central offices and academic departments of the university and describes the monitoring procedures for each area. The full text of Vanderbilt's subrecipient policy is available online at the following web address: https://www.vanderbilt.edu/ocga/docs/vupolicies/subrecipient/RevisedVUSubrecipientMonitoringGuidelines_effective12_26_2014.pdf Financial Aid: Assistance offered from institutional funds by Vanderbilt to our students is awarded on the basis of merit and/or financial need. Such assistance helps students and their families support the cost of attendance which includes tuition, mandatory fees, room & board, books, other course materials/supplies, and allowances for personal/miscellaneous and travel expenses. Merit-based awards are competitively awarded in recognition of academic achievement, leadership, and commitment to community service, contributions to society, and other forms of accomplishment. Need-based assistance is awarded on the basis of documented financial need, resulting from a need analysis evaluation accomplished in accordance with relevant and applicable federal, state, and/or institutional programs, policies, and eligibility requirements. The units responsible for administering student financial aid at Vanderbilt regularly initiate system-generated reviews, as well as other cross-checks on an ad hoc basis. Results from these reviews, along with recurring management reports, are regularly evaluated. Subsequently, follow-up corrective actions are taken when appropriate and potentially include award revisions or cancellations. These provisions are designed to help ensure that student assistance funds are awarded to eligible recipients, in accordance with applicable federal, state, institutional, and other program legislation, as well as relevant internal University policies and operational guidelines/criteria.

All financial aid grants and scholarships to students who are United States citizens are recorded in the financial aid management software, PowerFAIDS, by amount per semester. Student Financial Services staff determine student eligibility based on a consistently applied need analysis formula which calculates the expected family contribution (EFC). The EFC is subtracted from the total cost of attendance to equal the financial aid eligibility. The financial aid grant amount is determined based on consistently applied packaging formulas to meet the full calculated need of each student. In addition to the need based aid, there are some grants that are awarded based on merit or other factors. Financial aid grant funds are monitored through the financial aid management software, PowerFAIDS. Staff who will be awarding financial aid grant funds are trained to adhere to these policies and procedures. The financial aid grant information is transferred from PowerFAIDS to the student information system, Ellucian Colleague, via a regularly scheduled interface. When all institutional grant disbursement requirements are met, the funds are disbursed to the student account in Colleague. The funds are credited against any billed charges that have been previously posted. If this transaction results in a credit balance, the credit may be refunded to the student in the form of a check. The student initiates this refund process by submitting a completed Disbursement Form or Credit Balance Request Form. Student eligibility is monitored throughout the period of enrollment and adjustments are made, as necessary, for changes in enrollment status according to the College's published refund policies. During the fiscal year, the College conducted grant-funded research. Four of the research grants included collaboration with institutions whose faculty are accomplished in their respective fields of study. Infrequently at the discretion of the President or Vice President for Finance and Administration, the College makes donations to support the town or nonprofit organizations. In these instances, the College generally does not monitor the ultimate use of the funds as these amounts are unrestricted grants to municipalities and organizations that are recognized as being described in Internal Revenue Code Section 501(C)(3). In certain instances when the College grants funds for specified use by the town, the College maintains a written agreement that such grant will be used for the designated purpose.

THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID ADMINISTERS THE FOLLOWING POLICIES TO ASSURE THAT INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE USED FOR PROPER PURPOSES: THE AGGREGATE OF INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS THAT AN INDIFIVDUAL STUDENT RECEIVES IS RESTRICTED TO AN AMOUNT EQUIVALENT TO TUITION AND FEES; ENROLLMENT IS CONFIRMED EACH SEMESTER PRIOR TO DISBURSEMNET OF INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS; ELIGIBILITY FOR ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS IS LIMITED TO A MAXIMUM OF EIGHT SEMESTERS. RENEWAL GRADE POINT AVERAGE REQUIREMENTS ARE CHECKED AT THE END OF EACH ACADEMIC YEAR; ELIGIBILITY FOR INSTITUTIONAL GENERAL GRANTS REQUIRES A DEMONSTRATION OF NEED, BASED ON SUBMISSION OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA); ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS HAVE SELECTION CRITERIA SPECIFIC TO EACH FUND AND THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCAIL AID OVERSEES THE SELECTION OF ELIGIBLE STUDENTS; WHEN A STUDENT WITHDRAWS FROM SCHOOL, THE PERCENTAGE ADJUSTMENTS MADE TO INSTITUTIONAL AID ARE THE SAME AS THE PERCENTAGE ADJUSTMENTS MADE TO TUITION AS SPECIFIED IN THE CATALOG.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANTS FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS:THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAVEN IS COMMITTED TO ASSISTING STUDENTS IN FINANCING THEIR EDUCATION. THE UNIVERSITY OFFERS A COMPREHENSIVE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM, WITH THE STUDENTS RECEIVING ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENT LOANS, AND PART-TIME EMPLOYMENT WHICH ARE AVAILABLE FROM FEDERAL AND STATE FUNDS, PRIVATE SPONSORS, AND FROM UNIVERSITY RESOURCES. MORE THAN 90% OF THE UNIVERSITY'S FULL-TIME UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS RECEIVE SOME FORM OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. MOST FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE BASED ON AN INDIVIDUAL'S DEMONSTRATION OF NEED AFTER CAREFUL CONSIDERATION OF THE APPLICATION FOR ASSISTANCE. IN CALCULATING NEED, THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ATTEMPTS TO CONSIDER ALL ASPECTS OF A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL CIRCUMSTANCES. NEED-BASED AWARDS ARE ONLY AVAILABLE TO U.S. CITIZENS OR ELIGIBLE NON-CITIZENS. SOME FUNDS ARE AVAILABLE ON A MERIT BASIS FOR STUDENTS WHO HAVE EXCEPTIONAL ACADEMIC RECORDS OR ATHLETIC ABILITY. STUDENTS MUST BE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND BE IN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING IN ORDER TO BE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE FINANCIAL AID. GRADUATE STUDENTS MUST SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE ALL CREDITS FOR WHICH FINANCIAL AID HAS BEEN AWARDED, AS INDICATED ON THE STUDENT'S INDIVIDUAL FINANCIAL AID AWARD LETTER. FEDERAL, STATE, PRIVATE GRANT FUNDS AND INSTITUTIONAL AID FUNDS ARE NORMALLY APPLIED AS CREDITS TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

THE COLLEGE AWARDS MERIT-BASED SCHOLARHSIPS TO INCOMING FRESHMAN AS WELL AS CONTINUING STUDENTS. SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO FRESHMAN ARE DETERMINED BY THE ADMISSIONS COMMITTEE. ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE SCHOLARSHIPS IS DETERMINED THROUGH A COMBINATION OF THEIR UNDERGRADUATE CUMULATIVE SCIENCE GPA, RANKING OF THE COLLEGE ATTENDED, AND THE SCORE ACHIEVED ON THE MCAT, A STANDARDIZED MEDICAL SCHOOL ADMISSIONS TEST. FOR CONTINUING STUDENTS, THE TOP FIVE STUDENTS WITH A CUMULATIVE GPA OF 3.7 OR HIGHER FOR EACH GRADE, 2ND, 3RD, AND 4TH YEAR STUDENTS, RECEIVE THESE SCHOLARSHIPS. THE COLLEGE DOES NOT NEED TO MONITOR THE USE OF SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AS THOSE AMOUNTS ARE DIRECTLY SPENT TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION. THERE IS NO OPPORTUNITY FOR THE FUNDS TO BE DIRECTED FOR ANOTHER PURPOSE.

AS PART OF THE SENTARA HEALTHCARE SYSTEM ("THE SYSTEM"), THE ORGANIZATION DONATES FUNDS TO ITS SECTION 501(C)(3) PARENT ORGANIZATION, SENTARA HEALTHCARE, IN FURTHERANCE OF THE SYSTEM'S MISSION TO IMPROVE HEALTH EVERYDAY THROUGH THE PROVISION OF HEALTH SERVICES, AND THE PROMOTION OF HEALTH, MEDICAL EDUCATION, AND THE SOCIAL, CULTURAL, EDUCATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF THE COMMUNITY. EXPENDITURE OF SUCH FUNDS IS OVERSEEN BY AN INDEPENDENT COMMUNITY BOARD WHICH MANAGES THE BUSINESS AND AFFAIRS OF THE SYSTEM. THE ORGANIZATION ALSO DONATES FUNDS TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS WITH A SIMILAR MISSION OF PROVIDING AND PROMOTING HEALTH, MEDICAL EDUCATION, AND THE SOCIAL, CULTURAL, EDUCATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF THE COMMUNITY. SUCH ORGANIZATIONS ALSO HAVE COMMUNITY BOARDS WHICH OVERSEE THE PROPER EXPENDITURES OF SUCH FUNDS. THE ORGANIZATION'S COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS ON AN ON-GOING BASIS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED FROM QUALIFIED APPLICANTS ACCORDING TO PRESCRIBED GUIDELINES. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON A NONDISCRIMINATORY BASIS, AND THEIR USE IS MONITORED BY SCHOOL PERSONNEL.
THE GRANTS (SCHOLARSHIPS) MADE BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE A REDUCTION OF THE TUITION AND FEES PAID BY THE STUDENT TO THE SCHOOL. GRANT FUNDS ARE NOT SENT TO OUTSIDE ENTITIES.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE SERVES AS THE COORDINATING DEPARTMENT FOR ALL TYPES OF FUND RAISING PROGRAMS AND FOR SOLICITATION OF GIFTS. SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS/RESTRICTIONS ARE MADE AND MONITORED BY THE DEPARTMENTS OF FINANCIAL AID AND ACADEMIC AFFAIRS. THE ACCOUNTING STAFF RECORDS THE TRANSACTIONS IN SEPARATE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNTS.
ALL GRANT AND CONTRACT ACTIVITY IS MONITORED TO ASSURE THAT IT IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL APPLICABLE REGULATIONS. ALL EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED ON A WEEKLY BASIS FOR ALLOWABILITY.

FOR FINANCIAL AID GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS, THE COLLEGE AWARDS THESE TO STUDENTS EACH SEMESTER BASED ON SEVERAL FACTORS. THE AWARDS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT BALANCE FOR TUITION. FOR FACULTY DEVELOPMENT GRANTS, THE COLLEGE COLLECTS A DETAILED ACCOUNTING OF ALL GRANT RELATED EXPENDITURES ALONG WITH ALL CORRESPONDING RECEIPTS. ALL EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE RELATED TO THE GRANT AND THERE IS PROPER DOCUMENTATION. THE GRANT RECIPIENT ALSO SUBMITS A REPORT TO ACADEMIC AFFAIRS SUMMARIZING THEIR EXPERIENCE. ENTREPRENEURSHIP GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS, GRADUATES AND ALUMNI WHO ARE LAUNCHING OR GROWING BUSINESSES IN BALTIMORE. A PANEL OF JUDGES DETERMINES THE AWARDEES BASED UPON SEVERAL FACTORS. ALL GRANTS ARE MONITORED THROUGH PROGRESS REPORTING WHICH INCLUDE DESCRIPTIONS OF GRANT SUPPORTED ACTIVITIES THAT HAVE BEEN UNDERTAKEN SINCE THE GRANT PERIOD START DATE. THE GRANTEE ALSO SUBMITS A FINAL REPORT DESCRIBING BUSINESS ACTIVITY INCLUDING: LOCATION AND STATUS OF BUSINESS, JOBS CREATED OR LOST, CLIENT LIST AND LOCATIONS, STRATEGIC ADVISER LIST AND PAIN POINTS FOR ANY ADDITIONAL SUPPORT NEEDED. QUALIFIED DISASTER RELIEF PAYMENTS WERE AWARDED TO STUDENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE FEDERAL CARES ACT. Students who met basic eligibility criteria for federal financial aid received a qualified emergency relief payment.

EACH GRANT IS ASSIGNED A SEPARATE DEPARTMENT ACCOUNT NUMBER. REPORTS ARE THEN PRINTED WHICH SHOW ALL FUNDS RECEIVED AND DISBURSED. THESE GRANT REPORTS ARE PRINTED ON A MONTHLY BASIS BY THE PERSON RESPONSIBLE FOR THE GRANT. THE ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT ALSO PRINTS GRANT REPORTS ON A MONTHLY BASIS AS A CHECK THAT DISBURSEMENTS ARE NOT GREATER THAN FUNDS RECEIVED AND THAT FUNDS ARE BEING DISBURSED FOR GRANTS APPROVED.

ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are awarded to students based on the scholarship criteria. For example, a student may need to be an accounting major, with a GPA of 2.0 or higher. Students complete a scholarship application and the applications are given to a scholarship committee for review. The scholarship committee verifies the student meets the scholarship criteria and then determines the distribution.
ALL FINANCIAL AID THAT IS AWARDED IS CREDITED TO THE TUITION BILLING FOR THE STUDENT. ALL AID IS USED TO REDUCE THE TUITION PAYABLE.

The scholarship related records are maintained in the Financial Aid office of the University. There is a scholarship committee established to formulate guidelines and procedures as to the eligibility and criteria for each scholarship being awarded. Additionally, records supporting non-scholarship type grants are also maintained between grant accounting and the Office of Grants & Sponsored Research.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: STUDENTS TO BE AWARDED BY GRANTS ARE SCREENED BY THE SCHOOL. GRANTS ARE IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND DISCOUNTS WHICH ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

INDIVIDUALS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIP GRANTS AND FELLOWSHIP STIPENDS IN FURTHERANCE OF THE ORGANIZATION'S EXEMPT PURPOSE ARE DETERMINED TO BE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS BASED ON A REVIEW BY AN INDEPENDENT PANEL OF THE INDIVIDUAL'S ACADEMIC MERITS RELEVANT TO THE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM CONDUCTED AT THE INSTITUTE AND FINANCIAL NEED. EACH SEMESTER THE ORGANIZATION WILL REVIEW REGISTRATION RECORDS TO ENSURE THAT A STUDENT IS ENROLLED IN CLASSES BEFORE A SCHOLARSHIP OR FELLOWSHIP IS AWARDED. IF THE STUDENT WITHDRAWS BEFORE HALF OF THE SEMESTER IS COMPLETED, HE OR SHE IS REQUIRED TO REPAY THE ENTIRE SEMESTER'S AWARD. IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS AFTER THE HALFWAY POINT OF THE SEMESTER, HE OR SHE IS ENTITLED TO RETAIN THE FULL AWARDED AMOUNT. THE ORGANIZATION MAINTAINS A LISTING OF ALL SCHOLARSHIP AND FELLOWSHIP RECIPIENTS AND AMOUNTS AWARDED TO EACH STUDENT. ALL SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS ARE UNRELATED TO THE MEMBERS OF THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE AND ALSO UNRELATED TO THE OFFICERS AND DIRECTORS OF THE ORGANIZATION.
THE FUNDS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT, WHICH DIRECTLY OFFSETS TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD.
THE AMOUNT OF THE GRANT GIVEN TO THE GRANTEE IS SUBSTANTIATED BY THE ACCOUNTING SYSTEM AND AUDITED ANNUALLY.
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE PROVIDED AS A CREDIT TO THE STUDENT TO COVER CHARGES OF TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD, AND OTHER FEES RELATED TO THE COST OF ATTENDANCE.

ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE PROVIDED TO STUDENTS FOR TUITION ASSISTANCE TO ATTEND THE 2019-2020 ACADEMIC SCHOOL YEAR. CARES ACT STUDENT GRANTS ARE PROVIDED TO STUDENTS TO HELP COVER EXPENSES RELATED TO THE DISRUPTION OF STUDIES DUE TO COVID 19.

The College monitors enrollment and the Financial Aid Office of the College keeps the requisite records in either an electronic or hard copy form. No cash changes hands and funds are directly tied to student accounts.

For federal and pass-through grants for programs, each grant has a grant manager. On a monthly basis, the business office staff reconciles expenses incurred for each grant and verifies with the respective grant manager. Once confirmed, the business office staff requests reimbursement from the respective awarding agency. For scholarships, financial aid office staff reviews the specific criteria for awarding to students. The business office staff does a reconciliation of expenses (financial aid awarded) before drawing down actual dollars from the endowment and federal financial aid. For program endowments, there are two different methods used. Some programs have "budget managers" who are aware of the funds available via the business office staff and spend accordingly. For those programs without "budget managers and for unrestricted endowments, the business office staff ensures that there are expenses incurred in those specific departments before drawing down actual dollars. In all cases for the endowments, the business office staff does a reconciliation to ensure that the proper dollar amount is calculated, awarded/expensed, and drawn down.
THE SCHOOL PROVIDES RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNTS OF, AND REASON FOR, FINANCIAL AID GRANTED TO STUDENTS WISHING TO ATTEND.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF SCHOLASTIC ABILITY, PERSONAL PRESENTATION SKILLS AND FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS MUST MAINTAIN A MINIMUM GPA OF 2.5 TO QUALIFY FOR CONSIDERATION FOR ANY ADDITIONAL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING.

THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS A SEPARATE GRANT DEPARTMENT WHICH INCLUDES A DIRECTOR AND MULTIPLE GRANT ANALYSTS. THE GRANTS DEPARTMENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR COMPLIANCE WITH ALL CONTRACTUAL AND FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS AND FOR MAKING DETERMINATIONS REGARDING ELIGIBILITY.
The College provides scholarships under an application process.

BELMONT ABBEY COLLEGE UTILIZES VARIOUS DATABASES TO STORE AND MONITOR DATA PERTAINING TO THE AWARDING AND DISBURSEMENT OF GRANTS RECEIVED IN THE UNITED STATES. ALL GRANTS RECEIVED ARE PROPERLY APPLIED AS PAYMENTS TOWARD STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS APPROPRIATELY. ALL PARTICIPATING GRANTING ORGANIZATIONS HAVE COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS THAT ARE ADHERED TO AND AUDITED ANNUALLY IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE OFFICE OF BUDGET AND MANAGEMENT (OMB) UNIFORM GUIDANCE. AS SUCH, THE COLLEGE PRESENTS SCHEDULES OF EXPENDITURES OF FEDERAL AND STATE AWARDS SUMMARIZING ALL EXPENDITURES USING THE ACCRUAL BASIS OF ACCOUNTING.

STUDENTS AWARDED WITH AN HONOR SCHOLARSHIP MUST BE PART OF THE UNIVERSITY'S HONOR PROGRAM AND THIS PROGRAM HAS SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS THAT THE STUDENTS MUST MEET EVERY TRIMESTER IN ORDER TO RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIP. STUDENTS AWARDED WITH AN ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIP MUST MEET CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS ESTABLISHED BY THE ATHLETIC DEPARTMENT. STUDENTS ARE SELECTED BY A COMMITTEE PART OF THE VICE PRESIDENCY OF STUDENTS AFFAIRS.

Monterey College of Law provides scholarships to new and continuing students. The scholarships are awarded by a scholarship committee populated by members of the board of trustees. The scholarships are awarded each Fall and Spring semesters. Most scholarships are need-based or based on academic achievements. Monterey College of Law maintains complete records of the scholarship award amounts, evidence of good academic standing and criteria for scholarship selection.

ALL GRANTS REPORTED IN PART III OF SCHEDULE I ARE TO STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE WITH THEIR COSTS OF ATTENDANCE. GRANTS ARE ELECTRONICALLY TRANSMITTED BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID INTO THE ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE SYSTEM OF THE BUSINESS OFFICE BASED UPON SYSTEM IDENTIFICATION NUMBERS FOR INDIVIDUALS. EACH STUDENT IS ABLE TO COMPARE THE AID POSTED AGAINST HIS BILLING STATEMENT FOR TUITION AND FEES TO THE AWARD LETTER HE RECEIVED FROM THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. ADDITIONALLY, DURING THE COLLEGE'S ANNUAL AUDIT, THIS PROCESS IS TESTED FOR ACCURACY NOT ONLY OF AMOUNTS AND ASSIGNMENT TO CORRECT INDIVIDUALS, BUT ALSO FOR ANY RESTRICTIONS OF GRANT FUNDING REGARDING AWARDEE ATTRIBUTES REQUIRED TO QUALIFY FOR ANY PARTICULAR AWARD. LINE THREE IN PART III REPORTS THE FEDERALLY FUNDED SUPPLEMENTAL GRANTS; THE COLLEGE ANNUALLY CONTRACTS FOR AN AUDIT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE UNIFORM GUIDANCE.

GRANTS ARE PROCURED BY FACULTY WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF THE COLLEGE'S GRANT MANAGER. MONITORING IS DONE BY GRANTEE, GRANT MANAGER AND SENIOR ACCOUNTANT FOR COMPLIANCE. ACTIVITY IS AUDITED AND REPORTED ANNUALLY IN THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL STATEMENTS.
ALL FINANCIAL AID THAT IS AWARDED IS CREDITED TO THE TUITION BILLING FOR THE STUDENT. ALL AID IS USED TO REDUCE THE TUITION PAYABLE.
LA SALLE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS RECORDS TO QUANTIFY THE DOLLAR AMOUNT OF THE STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AWARDED, THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS PER GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP, AND THE SELECTION CRITERIA.

Grant funds are monitored through an electronic packaging program for all students. This electronic program determines eligibility for federal, state and institutional grant funding against a series of preestablished criteria. Once the program determines each student's eligibility for federal , state and intuitional grant funding. The information is also checked by a member of the Student Financial Planning staff.

WHEN DETERMINING THE DISTRIBUTION OF GRANTS AND LOANS TO STUDENTS, THE CULINARY INSTITUTE OF AMERICA COMPLIES WITH THE GUIDELINES OF THE U.S. DEPT. OF EDUCATION - TITLE IV REGULATIONS, NY STATE BOARD OF REGENTS AND THE ACCREDITING COMMISSION OF CAREER SCHOOLS AND COLLEGES OF TECHNOLOGY (ACCSCT) AND MIDDLE STATES ASSOCIATION COMMISSION ON HIGHER EDUCATION.

CORNELL MONITORS ALL GRANT RESOURCES THROUGH FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL AUDITS AS WELL AS FEDERAL, STATE, AND INTERNAL POLICY AND PROCEDURES AS WELL AS PERIODIC AUDITING BY AND REPORTING TO THE FEDERAL DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, AN INDEPENDENT AUDIT FIRM COMPLETES AN ANNUAL AUDIT OF ALL GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE CORNELL'S MANAGEMENT TAKES THE NECESSARY STEPS TO INSURE CORNELL IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE MANY FEDERAL REGULATIONS RECIPIENTS OF GRANT AND OTHER ASSISTANCE ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL OBJECTIVELY DETERMINABLE BASIS WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: WASHINGTON ADVENTIST UNIVERSITY USES THE SCHOLARSHIP AND STUDENT FINANCE COMMITTEE TO REVIEW AND AWARD ALUMNI DISCRETIONARY AND ALUMNI ENDOWMENT SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON CRITERIA SET FORTH BY EACH ENDOWMENT FUND. FEDERAL AND STATE GRANT MONIES ARE AWARDED BASED ON FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS AND ARE WRITTEN INTO THE BUSINESS RULES FOR THE ELLUCIAN SYSTEM. THE STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICE'S AID PROCESSOR IS ALSO THE COMPLIANCE OFFICER AND MONITORS COMPLIANCE WITH INSTITUTIONAL, STATE AND FEDERAL REGULATIONS FOR AWARDING AND DISBURSING OF AID MONEY.

PART I LINE 2 ATLANTIC GATEWAY COMMUNICATIONS INC. GRANT THE UNIVERSITY IS ACQUAINTED WITH THE ORGANIZATION AS IT HAS OWNED AND OPERATED THE RADIO STATION SINCE ITS INCEPTION. THIS IS A ONE-TIME DONATION THAT RESULTED FROM THE CONVEYANCE OF ALL ASSETS TO ATLANTIC GATEWAY COMMUNICATIONS, INC. ON SEPTEMBER 11, 2018.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Grants provided for Student Financial Aid are awarded by the Financial Aid Office based on appropriate guidelines. All awards are posted directly to the students' account and reviewed by the College's Business Office.

The financial aid office of the University tracks the scholarships issued to students through the financial aid module of our ERP system. It tracks the information from the awarding process through the posting and disbursement processes. Award amounts are posted directly to the student accounts. No cash is distributed directly to the students.

The Institution signed and returned to the Department of Education the Certification and Agreement document under Section 18004a1 of the CARES Act to provide Emergency Financial Aid Grants to students. TOTAL AMOUNT of Emergency Financial Aid Grants DISTRIBUTED to students was 757,146. The methods used by the institution to determine WHICH STUDENTS receive Emergency Financial Aid Grants and HOW MUCH they would receive A group of university representatives from Student Financial Services, Student Development, and all three academic programs worked on a method to determine which students would receive the HEERF grants. Because the intention was to promptly assist as many students as possible and understanding that all students were facing additional living and academic expense pressure due to the change in the academic delivery method, it was unanimously decided to provide a grant to all eligible students giving need priority to resident students who were inconvenienced the most after the university closed the residence halls.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required Uniform Guidance audit annually.
Grants are in the form of scholarships awarded to students and are given as a reduction of outstanding tuition.

Grants to governments and organizations are made and monitored by College personnel in support of local community relations. College's Grants to individuals are made and monitored in accordance with Federal and Institutional Financial Aid policies. Amounts are applied to student accounts as credits to the bill at the bursar's office to offset academic charges.

The Office of Financial Aid and Scholarships at Anderson University requires students to complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form to determine eligibility for federal, state and institutional grants, scholarships and loans. This is an equitable formula that measures all assets consistently. In addition to this form, the University does require some other guidelines in the event that funds are offered based upon certain academic credentials or performance in a University sponsored activity or athletic event. These credentials are clearly stated in the University catalog and the University website. Enrollment and eligibility are monitored by the University to ensure students remain eligible for funds awarded. No cash changes hands, and funds are directly tied to student accounts.

FUNDS ARE PROVIDED TO A RELATED ORGANIZATION TO ALLOW THAT ORGANIZATION TO FULFILL ITS MISSION BY FUNDING ITS OPERATING EXPENSES. GOODWILL INDUSTRIES OF MIDDLE GEORGIA, INC. PROVIDES CERTAIN OVERSIGHT FUNCTIONS TO THE RELATED ENTITY.

THE OFFICE OF SPONSORED RESEARCH IS REQUIRED TO REVIEW EACH REQUEST FOR PAYMENT PRIOR TO AUTHORIZATION OF PAYMENT TO A VENDOR OR PURCHASE. FOR FINANCIAL AID RELATED GRANTS THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID RECEIVES NOTICES OF AWARD AND AWARDS TO THE STUDENT BASED ON THE STIPULATIONS WITHIN THE GRANT. GRANT FUNDS ARE EACH ASSIGNED THEIR OWN FUND CODE TO ENSURE THAT GRANTS FUNDS ARE TRACKED PROPERLY, P.I.'S AND THE OFFICE OF SPONSORED RESEARCH HAVE ACCESS TO REVIEW EXPENDITURES TO ENSURE THAT ONLY APPROPRIATE COSTS HAVE BEEN CHARGED TO THE GRANT. THE OFFICE OF SPONSORED RESEARCH ALSO HAS WRITTEN PRE AND POST AWARD POLICIES AND GUIDELINES RELATED TO THE GRANTS FUNDS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID SERVICES AWARDS FINANCIAL AID IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE HIGHER EDUCATION ACT. FEDERAL AND STATE AWARDING GUIDELINES ARE USED IN AWARDING STUDENT'S FINANCIAL AID. STUDENT ACCOUNTS ARE REVIEWED ON A BI-WEEKLY BASIS TO ENSURE THAT ALL STUDENTS ARE CURRENTLY ENROLLED ACCORDING TO APPROPRIATE GUIDELINES. A QUALITY CONTROL CHECK IS IN PLACE IN THAT A FILE AUDIT IS PERFORMED OF A RANDOM SAMPLE OF FILES TO ENSURE THAT PROPER PROCEDURES ARE BEING FOLLOWED. AN ANNUAL AUDIT IS PERFORMED BY AN OUTSIDE COMPANY TO ENSURE THAT THERE ARE NO GROSS VIOLATIONS OF FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS.

ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES TO MONITOR GRANT USE ALL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON A NONDISCRIMINATORY BASIS. AMOUNTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TOWARDS A STUDENT'S TUITION, ROOM, AND BOARD COSTS, THEREBY ENSURING THE FUNDS ARE USED AS INTENDED. ADDITIONALLY, ANY ORGANIZATIONS AND ENTITIES RECEIVING SUBCONTRACT GRANTS FROM LOYOLA UNIVERSITY CHICAGO ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS ON THE USE OF THESE FUNDS. THESE PROGRESS REPORTS ARE MONITORED AND REVIEWED BY THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS TO ENSURE FUNDS ARE BEING USED APPROPRIATELY.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College undergoes the required Uniform Guidance audit annually.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANTS THE COLLEGE HAS A FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WHO HANDLES ALL FINANCIAL AID AWARDS. STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE AN APPLICATION FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE SUMMARIZES ALL THE RELEVANT DATA FROM THE APPLICATIONS. THE FINANCIAL AID STAFF REVIEWS ALL APPLICANTS AND SCHOLARSHIP REQUIREMENTS, THEN DECIDES WHO WILL RECEIVE THE AWARDS.

REGARDING THE MONITORING OF GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS TO INDIVIDUALS, ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS CURRENTLY ENROLLED AND ELIGIBLE FOR THE AWARDED AMOUNTS. THE AWARDS ARE APPLIED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. THE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED AND USED TO PAY FOR THE EDUCATIONAL COSTS AS DESCRIBED BY THE ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS

CLEVELAND CHIROPRACTIC COLLEGE OF LOS ANGELES IS A SUPPORTING ORGANIZATION OF CLEVELAND UNIVERSITY - KANSAS CITY. DUE TO THE OVERLAP OF DIRECTORS AND OFFICERS BETWEEN THE TWO ORGANIZATIONS, NO MONITORING OF THE GRANTS IS NECESSARY AFTER THE FACT.

INSTITUTIONAL AID AWARD TYPE: NEED BASED WHO AWARDS: FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AWARD TYPE: NEED BASED WHO AWARDS: FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT REVIEWS EACH APPLICANT WHO IS ELIGIBLE FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO DETERMINE IF THE APPLICANT QUALIFIES FOR A SPECIAL PROGRAM, SPONSORED AND FUNDED BY AMDA, CALLED THE "AMDA GRANT". THE AMDA GRANT IS A TUITION CREDIT GIVEN BY AMDA IN THE AMOUNTS OF $1,000 TO $4,000. THE DETERMINATION OF THE AMOUNT IS CALCULATED UTILIZING THE STUDENT'S EFC (ESTIMATED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION) OUTLINED IN THEIR SAR (STUDENT AID REPORT) WHICH IS BASED ON THEIR FAFSA INFORMATION. STUDENT'S WITH AN EFC FROM ZERO TO 15,000 WILL RECEIVE SOME TYPE OF AMDA GRANT. APPLICANTS: EVERY APPLICANT IS REVIEWED FOR ELIGIBILITY FOR THE AMDA GRANT WHEN THE APPLICANT IS BEING PACKAGED. THIS OCCURS UPON RECEIPT OF THE APPLICANT'S SAR (STUDENT AID REPORT), WHICH IS GENERATED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AFTER THE STUDENT HAS COMPLETED THEIR FAFSA. THE REVIEW OF AMDA GRANT ELIGIBILITY AND PACKAGING IS DONE BY THE FINANCIAL AID STAFF MEMBER THAT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE PACKAGING AND MANAGEMENT OF THE INCOMING STUDENT POPULATION FOR THAT RESPECTIVE CAMPUS. CURRENTLY ENROLLED STUDENTS: EACH STUDENT WHO IS CURRENTLY ENROLLED IS REVIEWED FOR ELIGIBILITY FOR THE AMDA GRANT WHEN THE STUDENT IS BEING PACKAGED AT THE BEGINNING OF EACH NEW ACADEMIC YEAR. AS WITH APPLICANTS, ELIGIBILITY IS CALCULATED ONCE THE STUDENT'S SAR HAS BEEN RECEIVED. SPECIAL CIRCUMSTANCES/NOTES: IF A PROFESSIONAL JUDGMENT IS COMPLETED TO REDUCE THE STUDENT'S INCOME AND THUS, EFC, WE WILL ALSO INCREASE THE STUDENT'S AMDA GRANT AWARD AMOUNT TO REFLECT THE NEWLY CALCULATED EFC. INTERNATIONAL GRANT AWARD TYPE: NEED BASED WHO AWARDS: FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS MAY SUBMIT AN INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL APPLICATION TO BE CONSIDERED FOR NEED BASED INSTITUTIONAL AID. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT REVIEWS EACH FINANCIAL APPLICATION TO DETERMINE IF THE APPLICANT QUALIFIES FOR A SPECIAL PROGRAM, SPONSORED AND FUNDED BY AMDA, CALLED THE "INTERNATIONAL GRANT". THE INTERNATIONAL GRANT IS A TUITION CREDIT GIVEN BY AMDA IN THE AMOUNTS OF $1,000 TO $4,000. THE DETERMINATION OF THE AMOUNT IS DETERMINED BY CALCULATIONS UTILIZING THE ESTIMATED ANNUAL INCOME, AS DETERMINED BY THE INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL APPLICATION, THEIR DEPENDENCY STATUS AND THE NUMBER OF DEPENDENTS IN THEIR HOUSEHOLD. INTERNATIONAL GRANTS ARE AUTOMATICALLY RENEWED FROM ONE ACADEMIC YEAR TO THE NEXT. APPLICANTS: INTERNATIONAL APPLICANTS WHO SUBMIT THE VOLUNTARY INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL AID APPLICATION ARE CONSIDERED FOR THE INTERNATIONAL GRANT. CURRENTLY ENROLLED STUDENTS: CONTINUING INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS, WHO WERE NOT AWARDED AN INTERNATIONAL GRANT DURING THEIR FIRST ACADEMIC YEAR, MAY BE CONSIDERED FOR THE INTERNATIONAL GRANT BY SUBMITTING AN INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL AID APPLICATION FOR THEIR CURRENT AWARD YEAR. SPECIAL CIRCUMSTANCES/NOTES: INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS MAY BE ASKED TO SUBMIT ADDITIONAL DOCUMENTATION TO VALIDATE INFORMATION STATED ON THE INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL APPLICATION. THIS DOCUMENTATION MAY INCLUDE TAX FORMS, BANK STATEMENTS, PAYROLL STUBS ETC. SUMMER GRANT AWARD TYPE: NEED BASED WHO AWARDS: FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT SUMMER GRANTS ARE $1,000 SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO ALL DOMESTIC APPLICANTS, DURING THEIR FIRST YEAR OF STUDY, IF THEY CHOSE TO START DURING THE SUMMER TERM AND THEY HAVE FILED A FAFSA AND HAVE AN EFC LESS THAN 10,000. APPLICANTS: ARE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE THE SUMMER GRANT IF THEY BEGIN ENROLLMENT DURING THE SUMMER TERM AND MEET THE EFC REQUIREMENT. CURRENTLY ENROLLED STUDENTS: CONTINUING STUDENTS ARE NOT ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE THE SUMMER GRANT. AMDA SCHOLARSHIPS AWARD TYPE: MERIT BASED WHO AWARDS: ADMISSIONS DEPARTMENT THE ADMISSIONS DEPARTMENT, SPECIFICALLY THE ADMISSIONS DIRECTORS, REVIEW EACH APPLICANT'S APPLICATION AND AUDITION RESULTS TO DETERMINE IF THE APPLICANT QUALIFIES FOR A SPECIAL PROGRAM, SPONSORED AND FUNDED BY AMDA, CALLED THE "AMDA SCHOLARSHIP". THE AMDA SCHOLARSHIP IS A TUITION CREDIT GIVEN BY AMDA THAT GENERALLY RANGE IN THE AMOUNTS OF $1,000 TO $10,000. THE DETERMINATION OF THE AMOUNT IS CALCULATED UTILIZING A RUBRIC ANALYZING SEVERAL COMPONENTS OF THE STUDENT APPLICATION AND AUDITION, SPECIFICALLY THEIR HIGH SCHOOL TRANSCRIPT/GPA, LETTERS OF RECOMMENDATION, ESSAY AND AUDITION SCORE. APPLICANTS: EVERY APPLICANT IS REVIEWED FOR ELIGIBILITY FOR THE AMDA SCHOLARSHIP DURING THE ADMISSION PROCESS. ONCE A SCHOLARSHIP DECISION HAS BEEN MADE IT IS ENTERING INTO POWERCAMPUS AND THE FINANCIAL AID COUNSELOR RESPONSIBILITY FOR PACKAGING THE PARTICULAR STUDENT'S POPULATION IS NOTIFIED. ONCE WE HAVE RECEIVED THE STUDENT'S SAR, THE APPLICANT IS THEN PACKAGED WITH THEIR AMDA SCHOLARSHIP, AS WELL AS ALL OTHER ELIGIBLE FINANCIAL AID. IF THE STUDENT IS NOT APPLYING FOR FEDERAL AID OR IS AN INTERNATIONAL STUDENT, THEN THEY WOULD BE PACKAGED WITH THEIR AMDA SCHOLARSHIP IMMEDIATELY UPON DETERMINATION AND NOTIFICATION. CURRENTLY ENROLLED STUDENTS: AMDA SCHOLARSHIP ARE RENEWABLE TO ALL CONTINUING STUDENTS FROM ONE ACADEMIC YEAR TO THE NEXT. AMDA SCHOLARSHIPS ARE RE-PACKAGED ONCE WE HAVE RECEIVED THE STUDENT'S NEW SAR AND ARE PACKAGING THEM FOR THE NEW ACADEMIC YEAR. AMDA SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE A MINIMUM GPA OF 3.0 TO MAINTAIN A SCHOLARSHIP FROM ONE ACADEMIC YEAR TO THE NEXT. STUDENTS WHO FALL BELOW THIS STANDARD WILL HAVE THEIR SCHOLARSHIP REMOVED WHEN BEING PACKAGED FOR THEIR NEXT ACADEMIC YEAR. SPECIAL CIRCUMSTANCES: STUDENTS WHO HAVE FALLEN BELOW THE 3.0 GPA MINIMUM STANDARD BUT MAY APPEAL TO HAVE THEIR SCHOLARSHIP RENEWED IF THEY HAVE EXTENUATING CIRCUMSTANCES THEY MAY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THEIR FAILURE TO MAINTAIN A 3.0 GPA OR THEY HAVE A GPA BETWEEN 2.50-2.99. INTERNATIONAL SCHOLARSHIP AWARD TYPE: MERIT BASED WHO AWARDS: ADMISSIONS DEPARTMENT THE ADMISSIONS DEPARTMENT, SPECIFICALLY THE ADMISSIONS DIRECTORS, REVIEW EACH INTERNATIONAL APPLICANT'S APPLICATION AND AUDITION RESULTS TO DETERMINE IF THE APPLICANT QUALIFIES FOR A SPECIAL PROGRAM, SPONSORED AND FUNDED BY AMDA, CALLED THE "INTERNATIONAL SCHOLARSHIP". THE INTERNATIONAL SCHOLARSHIP IS A TUITION CREDIT GIVEN BY AMDA THAT GENERALLY RANGE IN THE AMOUNTS OF $1,000 TO $10,000 AND IS SUPPLEMENTAL TO ANY AMDA SCHOLARSHIP ALREADY AWARDED. RECIPIENTS OF THIS AWARD ARE DETERMINED BASED ON FURTHER IN-DEPTH REVIEW OF THE APPLICANT'S ADMISSIONS MATERIALS INCLUDING THEIR APPLICATION AND AUDITION, SPECIFICALLY THEIR HIGH SCHOOL TRANSCRIPT/GPA, LETTERS OF RECOMMENDATION, ESSAY AND AUDITION SCORE. APPLICANTS: ONLY OUTSTANDING INTERNATIONAL APPLICANTS ARE CONSIDERED FOR THE INTERNATIONAL SCHOLARSHIP. CURRENTLY ENROLLED STUDENTS: INTERNATIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE RENEWABLE TO CONTINUING INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS FROM ONE ACADEMIC YEAR TO THE NEXT. INTERNATIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE RE-PACKAGED DURING THE FINANCIAL PACKAGING PROCESS FOR EACH NEW ACADEMIC YEAR. INTERNATIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE A MINIMUM GPA OF 3.0 TO MAINTAIN A SCHOLARSHIP FROM ONE ACADEMIC YEAR TO THE NEXT. STUDENTS WHO FALL BELOW THIS STANDARD WILL HAVE THEIR SCHOLARSHIP REMOVED WHEN BEING PACKAGED FOR THEIR NEXT ACADEMIC YEAR. SPECIAL CIRCUMSTANCES: STUDENTS WHO HAVE FALLEN BELOW THE 3.0 GPA MINIMUM STANDARD BUT MAY APPEAL TO HAVE THEIR SCHOLARSHIP RENEWED IF THEY HAVE EXTENUATING CIRCUMSTANCES THAT MAY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THEIR FAILURE TO MAINTAIN A 3.0 GPA AND THEY HAVE A GPA BETWEEN 2.50-2.99. VIP SCHOLARSHIP: AWARD TYPE: MERIT BASED WHO AWARDS: ADMISSIONS DEPARTMENT VIP SCHOLARSHIPS ARE $1,000 SCHOLARSHIP AWARDED TO APPLICANTS WHO SUBMIT A "VIP" APPLICATION. THIS $1,000 IS RENEWABLE FROM YEAR TO YEAR, IF THE STUDENT MAINTAINS THE MINIMUM 3.0 GPA REQUIREMENT. APPLICANTS: APPLICANTS ARE AWARDED THE VIP SCHOLARSHIP IF THEY ARE A RECIPIENT OF THE VIP APPLICATION CURRENTLY ENROLLED STUDENTS: CONTINUING STUDENTS MAY CONTINUE TO RECEIVE THE VIP SCHOLARSHIP IF THEY RECEIVED IT DURING THEIR FIRST YEAR AND MAINTAIN THE REQUIRED GPA. CONTINUING STUDENTS WHO DID NOT RECEIVE IT DURING THE FIRST YEAR ARE NOT ELIGIBLE FOR THIS SCHOLARSHIP. STUDENT SUPPORT AWARD: AWARD TYPE: NEED & MERIT BASED WHO AWARDS: SENIOR MANAGEMENT STUDENT SUPPORT AWARDS ARE SCHOLARSHIPS, IN VARYING AMOUNTS, THAT ARE AWARDED TO CONTINUING STUDENTS WHO ARE IN SEVERE FINANCIAL NEED INCLUDING A SUBSTANTIAL UNPAID BALANCE AND HAVE DEMONSTRATED ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE. APPLICANTS: APPLICANTS ARE NOT ELIGIBLE FOR STUDENT SUPPORT AWARDS CURRENTLY ENROLLED STUDENTS: STUDENT SUPPORT AWARDS ARE EVALUATED AFTER EACH ACADEMIC YEAR AND MAY BE RENEWED, BASED ON THE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDING AS DETERMINED BY SENIOR ADMINISTRATION. STUDENT MUST ALSO MEET ALL AWARD REQUIREMENTS TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR POSSIBLE RENEWAL.

HERF: AWARD TYPE: NEED BASED WHO AWARDS: FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT APPLICANTS: ARE ELIGIBLE IF THEY SUBMIT A 2019-20 FAFSA AND HAVE BEEN DETERMINED TO BE TITLE IV ELIGIBLE. STUDENTS ELIGIBLE TO SUBMIT A 19-20 FAFSA, WHO HAVE NOT YET DONE SO, MAY STILL SUBMIT A FAFSA UNTIL JUNE 30, 2020. STUDENTS SUBMITTING A LATE 19-20 FAFSA, MAY STILL BE AWARDED GRANT FUNDS, AS LONG AS THEY ARE DEEMED TITLE IV ELIGIBLE AND GRANT FUNDING REMAINS. GRANT AMOUNTS: GRANT AWARDS RANGE BETWEEN $250 - $1450 BASED ON STUDENT'S CURRENT ENROLLMENT STATUS AND THEIR ESTIMATED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC). THE EFC USED TO CALCULATE THEIR GRANT AWARD WAS TAKEN FROM THEIR MOST RECENT FAFSA TRANSACTION. GRANTS FUNDS WERE DISTRIBUTED TO STUDENTS BY EITHER; POSTING THE FUNDS DIRECTLY TO THEIR STUDENT REFUND ACCOUNT OR BY MAILED CHECK. GRANT RECIPIENTS, WHO DID NOT ALREADY HAVE A STUDENT REFUND ACCOUNT SET-UP, WERE ASKED TO EITHER; SET-UP AN ACCOUNT OR REQUEST A CHECK AND PROVIDE AN ADDRESS FOR THE CHECK TO BE MAIL.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS MATRICULATING AT THE COLLEGE, ALL FUNDS ISSUED TO STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION AND NO STUDENT MAY USE THE FUNDS FOR OTHER THAN EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. SINCE THE STUDENTS HAVE NO DISCRETION IN THE USE OF THE FUNDS, THE COLLEGE DOES NOT NEED TO MONITOR THE GRANTS ONCE ISSUED.

NSU Office of Sponsored Programs maintains a written, formal policy that outlines the procedures and guidelines for monitoring the use of sponsored funds by subrecipients. Prior to entering into a subaward agreement, NSU will assess subrecipient risk based on factors such as financial stability, experience with federal awards, quality of management systems and internal controls, and prior audit results. NSU will determine what type of monitoring activities are warranted based on risk, and develop a subrecipient monitoring plan. NSU will subsequently enter into a subaward agreement with each subrecipient which properly identifies prime award information, compliance requirements, and subrecipient monitoring documents required, as applicable. Throughout the period of performance, the Principal Investigator for the project monitors the programmatic activities of the subrecipient; determining that appropriate progress has been made; receiving, reviewing and retaining copies of required programmatic reports; and reviewing/approving subrecipient invoices prior to submitting to the NSU Office of Sponsored Programs for approval and processing. As part of the initial risk assessment and throughout the period of performance of the subaward, NSU will collaboratively review any deficiencies pertaining to the sponsored award that are identified through audits or other means, and issue a management decision. Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: Institutional grants awarded to students are recorded to individual student accounts and to each college departmental account using specific contra revenue account codes. The number of recipients and amount of awards varies by center and program. Funds set aside for scholarships are budgeted annually and included in the University's budget plan approved by the Board of Trustees.

THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS GUIDELINES SET FORTH BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND BY THE COLLEGE TO DETERMINE STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. STUDENTS QUALIFY FOR LINCOLN COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, SCHOLARSHIPS, EXTRA-CURRICULAR PARTICIPATION, AND NEED. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT HAS NUMEROUS POLICIES IN PLACE TO DETERMINE WHO RECEIVES, HOW THEY ARE ADMINISTERED, AND WHEN THE STUDENTS RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIP.

GRANT FUNDING IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS BY STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES WITHIN ESTABLISHED BUDGET LEVELS BASED ON UNIVERSITY POLICIES. GRANT FUNDS ARE CREDITED TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ACCOUNTS ELECTRONICALLY. STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES WORKS WITH ADVANCEMENT STAFF TO ENSURE THAT RESTRICTED FUNDS ARE AWARDED WITHIN ESTABLISHED CRITERIA, AND WITH FINANCE STAFF TO DETERMINE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS. STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES MAINTAINS INTERNAL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR THE CORRECT AWARDING AND ADJUSTING OF INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS. ANNUAL AUDITS ARE CONDUCTED TO ASSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES. NORTHEASTERN UNIVERSITY (NU) HAS A FULL TIME EMPLOYEE TO MONITOR ALL SUBAWARDS. - NU FOLLOWS FEDERAL REGULATIONS AS PART OF THE SUBRECIPIENT MONITORING UNDER UNIFORM GUIDANCE 2 CFR 200. - NU reviews the institutions single audit under Uniform Guidance through the Federal Audit Clearinghouse website. - Suspension and debarment statuses are reviewed in Sam.gov prior to each issuance. - DESK REVIEWS ARE PERFORMED, AND PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS APPROVE ALL INVOICES.
THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND TUITION WAIVERS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS ATTENDING THE UNIVERSITY AND ARE APPLIED TOWARD THEIR TUITION.

PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS INSIDE U.S. CONTRIBUTIONS MADE TO OTHER CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS ARE MADE PURSUANT TO UNIVERSITY POLICY. CONTRIBUTIONS BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE MADE WHERE THEY FURTHER THE UNIVERSITY'S MISSION OR ITS ROLE AS A GOOD COMMUNITY CITIZEN. IN MAKING A CONTRIBUTION, CONSIDERATION IS GIVEN TO THE ALIGNMENT OF THE RECIPIENT ENTITY'S VALUES WITH THOSE OF THE UNIVERSITY AND THE APPROPRIATENESS OF MAKING A CONTRIBUTION. ALL GRANTS, INCLUDING SUB-GRANTS, ARE ACCOUNTED FOR SEPARATELY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL ACCOUNTING SYSTEM AND EACH IS MANAGED BY A PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR. FINANCIAL ACTIVITY REPORTS ARE PROVIDED TO PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS ON A DAILY BASIS, WITH RECONCILIATION OF FINANCIAL REPORTS REQUIRED ON A MONTHLY BASIS. SUB-GRANTS ARE FURTHER MONITORED BY OBTAINING A GRANTEE'S A-133 AUDITS AND EVALUATING THE GRANTEE'S ABILITY TO COMPLY WITH THE TERMS OF THE SUB-GRANT. ALL GRANT MONITORING IS SUBJECT TO THE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES OF THE UNIVERSITY, WHICH ARE DESIGNED TO MEET FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS. THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF INSTITUTIONAL COMPLIANCE, OFFICE OF RESEARCH SERVICES, RESTRICTED ACCOUNTING AND OTHERS ARE CHARGED WITH ENSURING THAT ALL DEPAUL EMPLOYEES ARE AWARE OF THEIR RESPONSIBILITIES IN DEVELOPING AND MAINTAINING A COMPLIANCE-CONSCIOUS ENVIRONMENT. ADDITIONALLY, THE OFFICE OF INSTITUTIONAL COMPLIANCE, OFFICE OF RESEARCH SERVICES, RESTRICTED ACCOUNTING, PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS AND OTHERS ARE CHARGED WITH ENSURING THAT THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICIES AND PROCEDURES, AS WELL AS LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL LAWS ARE FOLLOWED. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH CONDUCTING RISK ASSESSMENTS, MONITORING OPERATIONAL ACTIVITIES, PROVIDING ONLINE, CLASSROOM AND/OR ONE-ON-ONE TRAINING AND OTHER TOOLS WHICH FOSTER COMPLIANCE.

GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS REPRESENTS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ADMINISTERED THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID SYSTEM. INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S INTERNAL ACCOUNT AND REPRESENT AN OFFSET TO TUITION AND OTHER FEES ASSESSED BY THE UNIVERSITY. GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE TO UNIVERSITY STAFF AND THEIR ELIGIBLE SPOUSE, DEPENDENTS, OR AN UNRELATED SECOND DOMICILED ADULT REPRESENT STAFF TUITION WAIVERS, PURSUANT TO A WRITTEN BENEFITS PLAN. STAFF TUITION WAIVERS ARE ADMINISTERED THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY'S BENEFITS SYSTEM AND, LIKE INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS FOR STUDENTS, ARE CREDITED TO THE INDIVIDUAL'S INTERNAL ACCOUNT TO OFFSET TUITION CHARGES. TAXABILITY OF TUITION WAIVERS IS DETERMINED PURSUANT TO SECTIONS 127 AND 117(D) OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE AND THEIR ACCOMPANYING REGULATIONS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO THE MASSACHUSETTS CONFERENCE FOR WOMEN AND THE GREATER BOSTON CHAMBER OF COMMERCE. THESE ENTITIES PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR BUSINESS NETWORKING, PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, EDUCATION, AND PERSONAL GROWTH FOR WOMEN. PART III THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS. MANY SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC STRENGTH, ATHLETIC ABILITY, AND LEADERSHIP OR COMMUNITY SERVICE. NON-NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING IS AWARDED THROUGH THE ADMISSIONS PROCESS AND USUALLY HAS A GRADE POINT AVERAGE (GPA) OR OTHER REQUIREMENT FOR RENEWAL IN SUBSEQUENT YEARS. TYPES OF MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS INCLUDE THE TRUSTEE SCHOLARSHIP, THE PRESIDENT'S SCHOLARSHIP, AND THE INTERNATIONAL SCHOLARSHIP. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO OFFERS GRANT FUNDS THAT ARE AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND DO NOT HAVE TO BE REPAID. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE DETERMINES THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF A STUDENT'S NEED-BASED GRANT FUNDING ACCORDING TO FEDERAL AND INSTITUTIONAL FORMULAS. TYPES OF NEED BASED GRANTS INCLUDE BENTLEY SCHOLARSHIPS, AS WELL AS FEDERAL AND STATE SOURCES. ALL SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNTS ARE AUTOMATICALLY CREDITED TO THE INDIVIDUAL'S STUDENT ACCOUNT.

The College ensures that its grants of student financial aid are used for the intended educational purpose by applying the awards directly to the students' tuition balances instead of issuing checks. The College also makes entrepreneurial and environmental grants through its Launch U Program and Green EDGE Fund. Potential grantees submit applications for the grants, and after a rigorous review process, grants are awarded. Grantees are required to submit reports which indicate how the grant funds were spent.

ALL FINANCIAL AID GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS WHO ARE UNITED STATES CITIZENS ARE RECORDED IN THE FINANCIAL AID MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE, POWERFAIDS, BY AMOUNT PER SEMESTER. STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES STAFF DETERMINE STUDENT ELIGIBILITY BASED ON A CONSISTENTLY APPLIED NEED ANALYSIS FORMULA WHICH CALCULATES THE EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC). THE EFC IS SUBTRACTED FROM THE TOTAL COST OF ATTENDANCE TO EQUAL THE FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY. THE FINANCIAL AID GRANT AMOUNT IS DETERMINED BASED ON CONSISTENTLY APPLIED PACKAGING FORMULAS TO MEET THE FULL CALCULATED NEED OF EACH STUDENT. IN ADDITION TO THE NEED BASED AID, THERE ARE SOME GRANTS THAT ARE AWARDED BASED ON MERIT OR OTHER FACTORS. FINANCIAL AID GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE, POWERFAIDS. STAFF WHO WILL BE AWARDING FINANCIAL AID GRANT FUNDS ARE TRAINED TO ADHERE TO THESE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES. THE FINANCIAL AID GRANT INFORMATION IS TRANSFERRED FROM POWERFAIDS TO THE STUDENT INFORMATION SYSTEM, ELLUCIAN COLLEAGUE, VIA A REGULARLY SCHEDULED INTERFACE. WHEN ALL INSTITUTIONAL GRANT DISBURSEMENT REQUIREMENTS ARE MET, THE FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT IN COLLEAGUE. THE FUNDS ARE CREDITED AGAINST ANY BILLED CHARGES THAT HAVE BEEN PREVIOUSLY POSTED. IF THIS TRANSACTION RESULTS IN A CREDIT BALANCE, THE CREDIT MAY BE REFUNDED TO THE STUDENT IN THE FORM OF A CHECK OR DIRECT DEPOSIT TO THE STUDENT'S BANK ACCOUNT. THE STUDENT INITIATES THIS REFUND PROCESS BY SUBMITTING A COMPLETED DISBURSEMENT FORM OR CREDIT BALANCE/REFUND REQUEST FORM. STUDENT ELIGIBILITY IS MONITORED THROUGHOUT THE PERIOD OF ENROLLMENT AND ADJUSTMENTS ARE MADE, AS NECESSARY, FOR CHANGES IN ENROLLMENT STATUS ACCORDING TO THE COLLEGE'S PUBLISHED REFUND POLICIES. DURING THE FISCAL YEAR, THE COLLEGE CONDUCTED GRANT-FUNDED RESEARCH. THREE OF THE RESEARCH GRANTS INCLUDED COLLABORATION WITH INSTITUTIONS WHOSE FACULTY ARE ACCOMPLISHED IN THEIR RESPECTIVE FIELDS OF STUDY. INFREQUENTLY AT THE DISCRETION OF THE PRESIDENT OR VICE PRESIDENT FOR FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION, THE COLLEGE MAKES DONATIONS TO SUPPORT THE TOWN OR NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS. IN THESE INSTANCES, THE COLLEGE GENERALLY DOES NOT MONITOR THE ULTIMATE USE OF THE FUNDS AS THESE AMOUNTS ARE UNRESTRICTED GRANTS TO MUNICIPALITIES AND ORGANIZATIONS THAT ARE RECOGNIZED AS BEING DESCRIBED IN INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SECTION 501(C)(3). IN CERTAIN INSTANCES WHEN THE COLLEGE GRANTS FUNDS FOR SPECIFIED USE BY THE TOWN, THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS A WRITTEN AGREEMENT THAT SUCH GRANT WILL BE USED FOR THE DESIGNATED PURPOSE.

FEDERAL CARES ACT HIGHER EDUCATION EMERGENCY RELIEF FUND EMERGENCY STUDENT AID As a result of the pandemic, the College was awarded $794,402 from the Higher Education Emergency Relief Fund (HEERF) during the fiscal year ended June 30, 2020. The funding was to provide emergency relief to students for expenses related to the disruption of campus operations due to COVID-19. The College disbursed $707,800 of the total received for students to assist students in their transition to remote learning, with the remaining $86,602 to be utilized in fiscal year 2021. The College was awarded an additional $794,401 from the HEERF to support institutional expenditures relating to the pandemic. The College utilized $707,800 in fiscal year 2020 and will utilize the balance for pandemic related costs in fiscal year 2021.

THE GRANTS ARE EXECUTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH EACH RESPECTIVE GRANT AGREEMENT. THEY ARE RECONCILED MONTHLY AS PART OF OUR MONTH END CLOSE PROCEDURE. EACH GRANT IS REPORTED TO ITS RESPECTIVE AGENCY AS REQUIRED IN THE GRANT AGREEMENT (I.E. MONTHLY, QUARTERLY, ONE TIME).
GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE ORGANIZATION'S FINANCE PERSONNEL THROUGH THE UTILIZATION OF COST CENTERS AND OTHER INFORMATION; INCLUDING WRITTEN DOCUMENTATION AND RECEIPTS.

PLEASE NOTE THAT CERTAIN GIFTS, GRANTS AND CONTRIBUTIONS PROVIDED TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS WERE LESS THAN OR EQUAL TO $5,000 EACH. THEREFORE, IN ACCORDANCE WITH FORM 990 RULES AND REGULATIONS THOSE CONTRIBUTIONS WOULD NOT BE INCLUDED WITHIN IN SCHEDULE I, PART II. THE TOTAL AMOUNTS PAID FOR CONTRIBUTIONS AND EVENT SPONSORSHIPS CAN BE FOUND WITHIN CORE FORM, PART IX, LINE 1.

FUNDS ARE DISTRIBUTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. STUDENT AID IS HANDLED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT. EACH STUDENT APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID BY FILLING OUT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). THE AWARD IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION IN THIS APPLICATION. STUDENTS CAN ALSO APPLY FOR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY. THERE IS AN AWARD ELIGIBILITY CALCULATOR ON THE HEIDELBERG WEBSITE TO SEE IF YOU QUALIFY.

ALL STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FEDERAL FUNDS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID ("FAFSA"). THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE REVIEWS THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA, WHICH DICTATES WHAT AND HOW MUCH FEDERAL FUNDING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR. IF THE STUDENT IS DETERMINED TO BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS, AS DETERMINED BY THE DEPT. OF ED., THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS THE STUDENT THE APPROPRIATE FUNDING. STUDENT FILES REGARDING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

The University awards grants, scholarships & student loans based on various, predefined criteria. Students must qualify for the assistance. Student enrollment and continuing eligibility are verified on an ongoing basis. Amounts are applied directly to student accounts and no cash changes hands.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College undergoes the Uniform Guidance audit annually.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 ALL GRANTS OR OTHER ASSISTANCE TO DOMESTIC ORGANIZATIONS OR DOMESTIC GOVERNMENTS ARE AUTHORIZED AND INITIATED BY THE PRESIDENTS OFFICE WITH STRICT CONTROLS OVER THE SELECTION AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE FUNDS. ALL SUCH GRANTS WERE MADE TO 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATIONS OR DOMESTIC GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES. FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS, NEED-BASED GRANTS, WORK-STUDY AND STUDENT LOANS. ELIGIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL AID VARIES BASED ON THE CRITERIA OF EACH AWARD. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT SUCH AS HIGH SCHOOL GRADE POINT AVERAGE, SAT OR ACT SCORE AND CLASS RANK, AND/OR EXTRA-CURRICULAR ACTIVITIES AND RECOMMENDATIONS. NEED-BASED GRANTS ARE OFFERED TO STUDENTS WHO COMPLETE A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND WHO, BASED ON THIS INFORMATION, MEET THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE NEED-BASED AID. ALL STUDENTS WHO ARE SELECTED FOR VERIFICATION BY THE CENTRAL PROCESSING SYSTEM (CPS) MUST ALSO SUBMIT VERIFICATION OF THE INFORMATION PROVIDED ON THE FAFSA. NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS INCLUDE THE FEDERAL PELL GRANT AND FEDERAL SUPPLEMENTAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY GRANT (SEOG), STATE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, AND EMMANUEL COLLEGE GRANT AID. IN ADDITION TO NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENTS WHO APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID AND DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED MAY ALSO RECEIVE FEDERAL WORK STUDY AND NEED-BASED FEDERAL AND STATE STUDENT LOANS. THE LOAN PROGRAMS OFFERED BY EMMANUEL COLLEGE ARE THE FEDERAL STAFFORD LOAN, THE FEDERAL PERKINS LOAN AND THE MASSACHUSETTS NO-INTEREST LOAN. PRIOR TO DISBURSING ANY FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR EACH GRANT, SCHOLARSHIP, WORK-PROGRAM OR STUDENT LOAN IS CERTIFIED. TO RECEIVE NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID EACH ACADEMIC YEAR.
THE ASSISTANCE IS IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS WHICH ARE AWARDED ANNUALLY BASED ON THE STUDENTS MEETING CERTAIN GPA STANDARDS AND EXTENT OF NEED.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS: USE OF GRANT FUNDING MUST COMPLY WITH THE INSTITUTION'S PURCHASING POLICY AND FEDERAL GUIDELINES. PRIMARY INVESTIGATORS ARE ULTIMATELY RESPONSIBLE FOR THE USE OF THOSE FUNDS UNDER THE REVIEW OF THE CONTRACT AND GRANTS ACCOUNTING MANAGER THAT MONITORS THEIR COMPLIANCE. IN ADDITION, THE COLLEGE IS SUBJECT TO AN ANNUAL AUDIT (UNIFORM GUIDANCE) ENSURING AN OUTSIDE OPINION ON THE INSTITUTION'S POLICIES AND PROCEDURES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES: THE FEDERAL AND STATE FUNDS PROVIDED FOR FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS OF ROSE-HULMAN FOLLOWS ALL REGULATIONS. EACH YEAR THE REGULATIONS ARE EVALUATED TO VERIFY THAT ALL REGULATIONS ARE BEING FOLLOWED BASED ON EACH FUNDS CRITERIA.

The School offers both need based and merit based financial assistance. Need based financial assistance is given in the form of grants to students with demonstrated need who would not otherwise be able to attend the school. All need based awards are reviewed annually. Applicants and returning families who are interested in need based financial aid must apply each year with current financial information by the published deadlines. Unless there is a significant change in a family's financial situation, returning students who meet the financial aid application deadlines can expect the level of aid to be consistent from year to year. If a boarding student becomes a day student or vice versa, the financial aid will adjust accordingly. The School also offers new students the opportunity to apply for two merit based scholarships each year - one for a boarding student and one for a Raleigh student. These scholarships are solely dependent on an applicant's merit and do not consider a family's financial need. Students who apply for either merit scholarship are also eligible to apply for need based assistance. Applicants must adhere to the deadlines and listed requirements in order to be considered for these scholarships.

The scholarship related records are maintained in the Financial Aid office of the University. There is a scholarship committee established to formulate guidelines and procedures as to the eligibility and criteria for each scholarship being awarded. Additionally, records supporting non-scholarship type grants are also maintained between grant accounting and the Office of Grants & Sponsored Research.
THE UNIVERSITY HAS A SPECIFIC DEPARTMENT RELATED TO STUDENT FINANCIAL AID THAT TRACKS ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANT FUNDS DISBURSED TO STUDENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Grants distributed by Dartmouth consist primarily of scholarships, fellowships and related support given to Dartmouth students. Scholarships are awarded based on the financial need of the student. Scholarship applications are reviewed by a financial aid officer. Financial aid officers are expected to recuse themselves from any case in which they either have a personal interest or feel they cannot be impartial. A random sampling of cases read by each undergraduate financial aid officer is reviewed by the Associate and Senior Associate Directors to ensure compliance with federal regulations, adherence to Dartmouth policies, consistency in results and accuracy. Scholarships are credited to an individual student's account through the Banner Student Information system after the student has enrolled for the term (these credits are included in "non-cash assistance" in Part III above) Scholarship funds are withdrawn if the student ceases to be enrolled. Fellowships are granted in support of a student's educational or research endeavors. All educational and research work is monitored by Dartmouth faculty.

THE ASSOCIATION MAKES CERTAIN ROUTINE GRANTS TO JOHN JAY COLLEGE OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE'S LIBRARY AND CHILDREN'S CENTER. THESE MONIES ARE USED TO SUPPORT THE ACTIVITIES OF THESE ENTITIES IN LINE WITH THE ASSOCIATION'S TAX-EXEMPT PURPOSE AND THE COLLEGE'S TAX-EXEMPT MISSION. THE ASSOCIATION IS NOT REQUIRED TO MONITOR THE USE OF THESE FUNDS AS IT IS GUARANTEED THAT THE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT STUDENTS' EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES.

VANGUARD UNIVERSITY AWARDS MERIT AND NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO TRADITIONAL UNDERGRADUATES AND MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO GRADUATE STUDENTS. AWARDS ARE BASED ON ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA INCLUDING ACADEMIC, TALENT AND PARTICIPATION, AND INCENTIVE INCLUDING DENOMINATION, MINISTRY/MISSIONARY DEPENDENT. CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY INCLUDING MAINTENANCE GPA IS MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. NEED-BASED AWARDS REQUIRE DEMONSTRATED NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE FAFSA AND REQUIRES FILING THE FAFSA BY THE MARCH 2 PRIORITY DEADLINE EACH YEAR AND CONTINUED DEMONSTRATION OF NEED. THE MAJORITY OF THE AWARDS ARE FUNDED BY THE INSTITUTIONAL AID BUDGET BUT SMALL NUMBER ARE FUNDED BY THE ENDOWMENT AND HAVE DONOR SPECIFIC CRITERIA. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WORKS WITH UNIVERSITY ADVANCEMENT AND FISCAL MANAGEMENT TO AWARD THESE FUNDS.
All grants are issued through the UDM Financial Aid office. The FA counselors communicate with students and monitor students' status and educational programs.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.: SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS: THE UNIVERSITY HAS A SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE THAT SELECTS ALL SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS. THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO STUDENTS BASED ON BOTH MERIT AND NEED. OTHER ASSISTANCE: All OTHER ASSISTANCE given to organizations are donations to the organization in support of their exempt purpose. The university does not monitor the use of grant funds due TO the nature of the donation.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY'S MONITORING PROCEDURES INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING STEPS: 1, PERFORM A RISK ASSESSMENT ON SUB-RECIPIENT 2, PERFORM SITE VISITS TO REVIEW FINANCIAL AND PROGRAMMATIC RECORDS 3, ENSURE THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR HAS REGULAR CONTRACTS 4, ENSURE A CURRENT CERTIFICATION OR A-133 AUDIT IS PERFORMED AND THE RELATED REPORT RECEIVED AND REVIEWED.

ERAU IS NOT A GRANTMAKING ORGANIZATION PER SE IN THAT ITS FUNDAMENTAL MISSION AND PURPOSE FOR TAX-EXEMPT STATUS RELATES TO EDUCATION. HOWEVER, IN THE COURSE OF ITS MISSION-RELATED ACTIVITIES, ERAU DOES MAKE PAYMENTS THAT MEET THE DEFINITION OF "GRANTMAKING" AS DEFINED BY THE INSTRUCTIONS TO SCHEDULE I OF FORM 990. THESE PAYMENTS FALL INTO TWO CATEGORIES: (1) STUDENT FINANCIAL AID: ERAU OFFERS STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS WHICH ARE PROVIDED BY ERAU AND FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS. ERAU'S FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO DEMONSTRATE ELIGIBILITY BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED, COMPETE IN INTERCOLLEGIATE ATHLETICS, DEMONSTRATE ACADEMIC MERIT, ETC. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID DETERMINES STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID. (2) CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS: CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH ERAU POLICY AND ALL APPLICABLE LAWS AND REGULATIONS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part III, Line 2, Column (C)
ExplntnTxt: AMOUNTS OF CASH GRANTS REPRESENT CORONAVIRUS AID, RELIEF, AND ECONOMIC SECURITY (CARES) ACT EMERGENCY FINANCIAL AID GRANTS TO STUDENTS.

FOR INDIVIDUAL RECIPIENTS OF GRANTS, ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE AND DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED ARE USED TO DETERMINE EACH STUDENT'S FINANCIAL AID. THE FINANCIAL AID CONSISTS OF ANY COMBINATION OF GRANTS AND LOANS AND ARE REVIEWED EACH YEAR BASED ON A STUDENT'S ACADEMIC RECORD AND/OR DEMONSTRATED NEED. THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID, WHICH HELPS TO ESTABLISH A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED, SERVES AS THE APPLICATION FOR TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS. SIMMONS UNIVERSITY ALSO PASSES GRANTS THROUGH TO OTHER SECTION 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATIONS THAT ARE SUBRECIPIENTS OF GRANT FUNDS.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS ATTENDING BROOKLYN LAW SCHOOL AND ARE A DIRECT OFFSET OF TUITION. FELLOWSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS UNDER STRICT SELECTION CRITERIA. LOAN FORGIVENESS ARE PAID DIRECTLY TO THE LENDER OR REQUIRES PROOF OF DEBT REDUCTION FROM THE STUDENT.

THE TOTAL GRANTS REPORTED IN PART III DOES NOT TIE TO THE TOTAL OF $26,988,636 AS REPORTED ON FORM 990, PART IX, LINE 2. THIS IS DUE TO AN ACCRUAL REVERSAL ADJUSTMENT ON LOAN FORGIVENESS PROGRAM THAT IS BEING NETTED WITH THE TOTAL GRANT EXPENSE OF $26,988,636 REPORTED ON FORM 990, PART IX, LINE 2.

GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE AWARDED TO INDIVIDUALS WITHIN THE UNITED STATES REPRESENT STUDENT FINANCIAL AID & SCHOLARSHIPS. FULL FINANCIAL SUPPORT IS OFFERED TO ALL STUDENTS. ALL PHD STUDENTS AT TTIC MAY EXPECT TO RECEIVE FINANCIAL SUPPORT THAT COVERS TUITION AND A STIPEND TO ASSIST WITH LIVING EXPENSES.

YESHIVA OF GREATER WASHINGTON (YGW) ALLOCATES GRANT FUNDS FROM THE OPERATIONAL BUDGET FOR STUDENT TUITION ASSISTANCE. AWARDS ARE BASED ON DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED THROUGH THE SUBMISSION OF A TUITION ASSISTANCE APPLICATION AND SUPPLEMENTAL INCOME TAX FORMS. GRANT AWARDS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT TO OFFSET THE FULL RATE TUITION AND FEES AND THERE ARE NO ACTUAL DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS TO RECIPIENTS.

A SIGNIFICANT PORTION OF INSTITUTIONAL AID AWARDED TO STUDENTS IS BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT, FOR WHICH THE UNIVERSITY HAS A PREDETERMINED GRID THAT PROVIDES THE AMOUNTS TO BE AWARDED BASED ON THE STUDENT'S ACTUAL GPA AND TEST SCORES AND, AS NEEDED, EVALUATION BY THE UNIVERSITY'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE. OTHER INSTITUTIONAL AID CONSISTS OF RETURNED MISSIONARY SCHOLARSHIPS, TALENT, AND OTHER NEED-BASED GRANTS. RETURNED MISSIONARY SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED PER YEAR TO ALL FULL-TIME STUDENTS WHO HAVE COMPLETED A MISSION FOR THE CHURCH OF JESUS CHRIST OF LATTER-DAY SAINTS OR SIMILAR SERVICE. TALENT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED IN VARIOUS AMOUNTS, TYPICALLY BETWEEN $500 AND $2,000 PER STUDENT, AND ARE AWARDED BASED ON THE NOMINATION OF THE UNIVERSITY FACULTY, ART/THEATRE/MUSIC DIRECTOR, ETC. AND APPROVAL OF THE FINANCIAL AID COMMITTEE. UNIVERSITY NEED BASED GRANTS AND VARIOUS OTHER GRANTS ARE AWARDED AS DETERMINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR. FEDERAL & STATE GRANTS, INCLUDING PELL, SEOG, AND VTAG ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND MEET THE VARIOUS QUALIFICATIONS. FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS ARE VERIFIED INTERNALLY BY OUR FINANCIAL AID STAFF AS DICTATED BY APPLICABLE REGULATION.
THE UNIVERSITY OF NORTHWESTERN OHIO AWARDS FINANCIAL AID GRANTS TO STUDENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID POLICIES.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANTS FUNDS IN U.S. AS PART OF THE SENTARA HEALTHCARE SYSTEM ("THE SYSTEM"), THE ORGANIZATION DONATES FUNDS TO SENTARA HEALTHCARE, THE 501(C)(3) PARENT ORGANIZATION OF THE SYSTEM, IN FURTHERANCE OF THE SYSTEM'S MISSION TO IMPROVE HEALTH EVERYDAY THROUGH THE PROVISION OF HEALTH SERVICES, AND THE PROMOTION OF HEALTH, MEDICAL EDUCATION, AND THE SOCIAL, CULTURAL, EDUCATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF THE COMMUNITY. EXPENDITURE OF SUCH FUNDS IS OVERSEEN BY AN INDEPENDENT COMMUNITY BOARD WHICH MANAGES THE BUSINESS AND AFFAIRS OF THE SYSTEM. SENTARA RMH MEDICAL CENTER HAS A CAREFUL SCREENING PROCESS IN REVIEWING GRANT APPLICANTS. THE APPLICATIONS ARE FIRST REVIEWED BY A SMALL COMMITTEE USING ESTABLISHED CRITERIA SUCH AS: 1) WHAT COMMUNITY NEED IS BEING ADDRESSED, 2) THE ROLE OF PARTNERS IN THE INITIATIVE, 3) AN ACTION PLAN WITH SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES, 4) MEASURABLE GOALS OR OUTCOMES, 5) BUDGET, AND 6) SUSTAINABILITY FOR THE PROJECT IN THE FUTURE. IF AWARDED THE GRANT, THE APPLICANT IS REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A WRITTEN REPORT OF THE OUTCOME WITHIN 12 MONTHS. NO GRANTS ARE MADE OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES.

THE INSTITUTE'S STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, INCLUDING ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA. THIS OFFICE ENSURES THAT FUNDS ARE PROPERLY CREDITED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AND MONITORS STUDENTS' CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY TO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: The college reports are regularly reviewed to be certain funds are used for proper purposes. Federal grant reporting and reconciliation occurs monthly and during the yearly single audit. Awarding practices are reviewedforcompliance with federal regulations. Students are reviewed yearly for continued and new fund eligibility to be sure academic standards and other grant-specific criteria have been met.

The College has a limited amount of funds available each year to be used for student aid in the form of scholarships. Each scholarship has clearly defined eligibility requirements. Some scholarships such as academic merit are automatically awarded if eligible criteria are met. In other cases students make applications for each scholarship they wish to be considered. The Director of Financial Aid and/or Committee reviews scholarship applications and awards scholarships. No cash changes hands and funds are directly tied to student accounts.
THE UNIVERSITY HAS POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND COMPLIES WITH THE FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR AWARDING STUDENT AID.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS ALL STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, OR OTHER ASSISTANCE ARE MONITORED THROUGHOUT THE AWARD, ACCEPTANCE, AND APPLICATION PROCESSES. APPROPRIATE RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED AND DOCUMENTED.
THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS AN OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID, WHICH IS REPONSIBLE FOR THE MONITORING OF GRANT FUNDS AWARDED TO THE COLLEGE AND STUDENTS.

GRANT RECIPIENTS ARE STUDENDS ENROLLED IN THE MASTER OF DIVINITY PROGRAM AND ARE CHOSEN BASED ON NUMBER OF CREDIT HOURS COMPLETED IN THE DEGREE PROGRAM, NUMBER OF CREDIT HOURS TAKEN EACH TERM, AND FINANCIAL NEED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE IN THE UNITED STATES
ExplntnTxt: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS MATRICULATING AT THE COLLEGE; THESE SCHOLARSHIPS MAY ONLY BE USED BY STUDENTS TO DEFRAY THE COSTS OF TUITION AND/OR ROOM AND BOARD. SINCE THE STUDENTS MAY NOT EXERCISE ANY DISCRETION ON HOW THE FUNDS ARE SPENT, THE COLLEGE IS NOT REQUIRED TO MONITOR THE GRANTS (OTHER THAN TO ENSURE THAT THE STUDENT IS FULFILLING THE REQUIREMENTS FOR EARNING THE SCHOLARSHIP).

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY OF DAYTON IS AN INDEPENDENT UNIVERSITY THAT PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO ITS STUDENTS. THE STUDENTS QUALIFY TO RECEIVE THIS AID BASED UPON THEIR FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC TALENT. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED THAT DOCUMENT THE STUDENTS' FINANCIAL NEED, ELIGIBILITY TO QUALIFY FOR THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS AND THE AMOUNTS AWARDED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Federal and state programs are administered according to the laws, rules, statutes, and regulations as issued by the State of California and the U.S. Department of Education as well as the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. University scholarships and grants are administered according to the policies and procedures developed and implemented by the Financial Aid Office in support of the University's strategic enrollment plan. The Financial Aid Office uses the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) as well as a number of supporting documents of verification to determine a student's eligibility for all need based programs. In addition, students are reviewed based on academic qualifications and special talents for merit based programs such as music, athletics, regents scholarships and similar programs. Policies and Procedures ensure that the determination of aid eligibility and the subsequent delivery of aid from any and all programs are done in a fair and equitable manner and in accordance with the rules and regulations that govern the individual programs.

ALL STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FEDERAL FUNDS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID ("FAFSA"). THE AID OFFICE REVIEWS THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA, WHICH DICTATES WHAT AND HOW MUCH FEDERAL FUNDING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR. IF THE STUDENT IS DETERMINED TO BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS, AS DETERMINED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, THE AID OFFICE AWARDS THE STUDENT THE APPROPRIATE FUNDING. STUDENT FILES REGARDING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.
THE SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED ARE MONITORED THROUGHOUT THE SEMESTER.

HAWAII PACIFIC UNIVERSITY'S OFFICES OF FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS OVERSEE FEDERAL AND UNIVERSITY GRANT, SCHOLARSHIP, LOAN AND WORK-STUDY PROGRAMS. FEDERAL PROGRAMS ARE ADMINISTERED ACCORDING TO THE LAWS, RULES AND REGULATIONS ISSUED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES, OR OTHER GRANTING AGENCY. UNIVERSITY SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE ADMINISTERED ACCORDING TO THE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES IMPLEMENTED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO SUPPORT THE UNIVERSITY'S ENROLLMENT PLAN. THE OFFICES AWARD AID BASED ON THE FEDERAL FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTATION TO VERIFY A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED BASED PROGRAMS AND SCHOLARSHIPS WHERE NEED IS A CRITERIA. IN ADDITION, STUDENTS ARE REVIEWED BASED ON ACADEMIC AND TALENT QUALIFICATIONS FOR MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS IN AREAS SUCH AS DANCE, ATHLETICS, MUSIC, DEBATE AND OTHER AREAS. PRESIDENT'S SCHOLARS SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON MERIT, GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND RECOMMENDATIONS. FINANCIAL AID AND THE SCHOLARSHIPS OFFICES MONITOR THE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY OF STUDENTS FOR AWARDS.

The college's Office of Student Financial Services is responsible for awarding and monitoring all college, federal and state grant, loan and work assistance. More than 75% of Wheaton students receive some form of financial aid and all students who demonstrate need receive aid. Financial assistance at Wheaton is awarded on the basis of demonstrated need and academic performance. "Need" is determined by the financial information that a student and his/her family provides on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and Wheaton Institutional Financial Aid Application which capture the data required to determine eligibility based on federal and/or state regulations and institutional fund eligibility guidelines. A need-based package may include a merit scholarship, grants, loans or work award. When funds are awarded, student eligibility is monitored through the college's operational system financial aid module to ensure there are no changes in status that might affect their ongoing eligibility. Total grant funds awarded are tracked to ensure compliance with budgeted amounts.
FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS ACCORDING TO THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION REGULATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS AND MOUNT CARMEL HEALTH SYSTEM FOUNDATION REQUIREMENTS.
THE MEDICAL CENTER ONLY MAKES GRANTS TO ITS RELATED, TAX-EXEMPT FOUNDATION BEEBE MEDICAL FOUNDATION.

THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IF THE STUDENT HAS EXCESS SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AS THE RESULT OF TITLE IV AID, THEN THESE FUNDS ARE AUTOMATICALLY DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT WITHIN 14 DAYS. IF THE EXCESS FUNDS ARE THE RESULT OF SOMETHING OTHER THAN TITLE IV AID, THE STUDENT MUST REQUEST A REFUND AND THESE FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK. THE UNIVERSITY'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. ARE AS FOLLOWS: THE UNIVERSITY HAS APPOINTED DIRECTORS, WHO REPORT TO THE APPROPRIATE VICE PRESIDENTS OVER ALL FEDERAL GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE DIRECTORS ARE CHARGED WITH PERFORMING ALL GRANT-RELATED ACTIVITIES INCLUDING APPLICATION, MONITORING OF EXPENDITURES AND REPORTING, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF DRAW-DOWNS OF FEDERAL FUNDS. DRAW-DOWNS ARE PERFORMED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S CONTROLLER AFTER REQUESTS ARE MADE BY THE DIRECTOR TO THE CONTROLLER. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS THE REQUESTS FOR DRAW-DOWNS, WHICH INCLUDE DOCUMENTATION OF ALL DIRECT AND INDIRECT PROGRAM EXPENSES, BEFORE MAKING THE DRAW-DOWNS. A SINGLE AUDIT IS PERFORMED ANNUALLY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S INDEPENDENT AUDITORS.

WLC AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS MEETING CERTAIN FINANCIAL NEED TESTS AND ACADEMIC MERIT LEVELS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINE ARTS ABILITIES, FINANCIAL NEED, OR OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS SET BY THE BOARD OF REGENTS OR DONORS OF RESTRICTED OR ENDOWED FUNDS.
THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED THROUGH THE ORGANIZATION'S ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT WHEREBY STUDENT'S TUITION PAID IS CREDITED WITH GRANT SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNTS AS EARNED.

THE UNIVERSITY'S USE OF GRANT FUNDS IS TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL AID TO OUR STUDENTS. WE MONITOR THE USE OF THESE UNIVERSITY FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH ESTABLISHED LEVELS OF AWARDS BASED ON A STUDENT'S MERIT CLASSIFICATION AND ON AN ANNUAL BUDGET. THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL REGULATIONS RELATIVE TO THE AWARDING OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE WHICH IS MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: All grant expenditures are reviewed by the Grant Accountant for reasonableness, allowable expenditures, and compliance to the grant regulations and criteria. All scholarships and assistance are provided as a credit to the student's tuition account.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES ITS STUDENTS WITH VARIOUS SCHOLARSHIPS THAT ARE AWARDED BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA. EACH STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY IS VERIFIED PRIOR TO AWARDING. THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS THE GRANTS DIRECTLY TO OUTSTANDING BALANCES TO ENSURE THE PROPER USE OF AWARDED FUNDS.
SCHOLARSHIPS AND DISCOUNT AMOUNTS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE POSTED DIRECTLY
TO EACH STUDENTS ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE SUBSIDIARY ACCO
Student eligibility data was matched against scholarship and grant award criteria prior to awarding of funds.
ALL GRANTS ARE INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID AND APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT BY KANSAS CITY ART INSTITUTE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Disbursements in furtherance of the University's exempt programs are made in accordance with procedures or subject to conditions established by the institution's governing board designed to insure that individuals and organizations receiving disbursements from the organization in furtherance of its exempt programs are adequately investigated to insure that they are qualifying recipients.
