CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS ALSO REQUIRE THE APPROVAL OF THE EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, EXCEPT FOR THOSE CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS MADE THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY'S DONOR ADVISED FUND PROGRAM, WHICH UNDERGO A THOROUGH VETTING PROCESS BY THE UNIVERSITY'S TAX DEPARTMENT TO ENSURE THE RECIPIENT ORGANIZATION MEETS THE IRS'S DEFINITION OF A 501(C)(3) NOT FOR PROFIT CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES FUNDING TO STUDENTS AND OTHER RELATED INDIVIDUALS FOR RESEARCH AND OTHER ACTIVITIES TO SUPPORT THE FURTHERANCE OF THEIR EDUCATION. FUNDS PROVIDED ARE MONITORED THROUGH APPLICATIONS, BUDGETS AND A REQUIREMENT TO DOCUMENT THE USE OF FUNDS EITHER PRIOR TO THE DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS OR UPON COMPLETION OF THE ACTIVITY.

THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS USING ESTABLISHED POLICIES ON THE BASIS OF BOTH NEED AND SCHOLARSHIP MERIT. AWARDS TO STUDENTS WITH NEED ARE BASED ON THE STUDENTS' FINANCIAL INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THE FINANCIAL AID PROFILE FILED WITH THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICES AND THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FINANCIAL AID FILED WITH THE FEDERAL PROCESSOR. ALL AID IS OBJECTIVELY DETERMINED AND AWARDED ON AN EQUAL BASIS TO RECIPIENTS WITH SIMILAR ATTRIBUTES.
INQUIRY BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES WHETHER THE GRANTEES CONTINUE TO COMPLY WITH THEIR STATED PURPOSE.

MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO ENROLLED STUDENTS ARE CREDITED TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNT TO COVER TUITION AND FEES. GRADE REPORTS ARE GENERATED FOR EACH TERM AND EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS REVIEWED TO INSURE THEY ARE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS TO MAINTAIN THEIR GRANT OR SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING. NOTIFICATIONS ARE SENT BY THE DEAN OF THE COLLEGE TO ALERT DEPARTMENTS OF WITHDRAWALS. ALSO, FINANCIAL AID RUNS ENROLLMENT REPORTS EACH TERM TO CHECK THE NUMBER OF CREDIT HRS FOR EACH STUDENT. THIRD PARTY SOFTWARE IS ALSO CODED TO PREVENT THE CREDIT OF FUNDS TO A STUDENT WITHOUT ENROLLED HOURS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 ALL FUNDS DONATED BY INDIVIDUALS, CORPORATIONS OR FOUNDATIONS ARE RECORDED AS TEMPORARILY RESTRICTED UNTIL FUNDS ARE IDENTIFIED AS APPLICABLE TO FINANCIAL AID FOR A STUDENT. FUNDS ARE SUBSEQUENTLY CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS. ALL AWARDS ARE UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH DONORS' DIRECTIONS.

SCHEDULE I, PART III SCHOLARSHIPS FOR WOMEN MAKING LIFE CHANGES THROUGH EDUCATION, PER DONOR RESTRICTIONS, AMOUNTED TO $ 101,140 SCHOLARSHIP FOR TEACHERS AND SOCIAL SERVICES STUDENTS IN THE BOSTON AREA SEEKING TO ADVANCE THEIR CAREERS THROUGH EDUCATION, PER DONOR RESTRICTIONS, AMOUNTED TO $ 27,279 SCHOLARSHIPS FOR STUDENT WORKING TOWARDS CIVIL RIGHTS AND SOCIAL JUSTICE IN THEIR PERSONAL LIVES OR EDUCATION, PER DONOR RESTRICTIONS, AMOUNTED TO $ 71,877 SCHOLARSHIPS FOR STUDENTS MAKING LIFE CHANGES THROUGH EDUCATION, PER DONOR RESTRICTIONS, AMOUNTED TO $ 6,862 SCHOLARSHIPS FOR MALE PROTESTANT STUDENTS FROM BOSTON AREA SCHOOLS, PER DONOR RESTRICTIONS, AMOUNTED TO $ 1,502 STUDENTS WITH HERITAGE FROM LAOS, BURMA, CAMBODIA, AND VIETNAM AMOUNTED TO $ 12,933 THE REMAINING $611,225 IS COMPRISED OF FINANCIAL AID ($346,444), MASSACHUSETTS GRANTS ($145,800), AND WAIVERS & DISCOUNTS ($118,981).

DESCRIPTION OF ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS IN THE APPLICATION FOR SUPPORT, A DETAILED EXPLANATION OF THE KIND OF SERVICES PROVIDED TO THE COMMUNITY ALONG WITH SPECIFIC FINANCIAL DATA IS REQUESTED. IF THE APPLICATION FOR SUPPORT IS APPROVED, A LETTER IS SENT INDICATING THE AMOUNT OF THE SUPPORT ALONG WITH A REQUEST FOR DOCUMENTATION OF HOW THE FUNDS WERE USED, ALONG WITH A REPORT OF THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN/FAMILIES SERVED OVER THE YEAR. GRANTS MADE TO AFFILIATED FOUNDATIONS ARE MONITORED ON A MONTHLY BASIS AS THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS OF THESE ORGANIZATIONS ARE READILY AVAILABLE. OTHER GRANTS ARE MADE THAT COMPLY WITH THE MISSION AND FURTHER THE TAX-EXEMPT PURPOSE OF THE ORGANIZATION.
ASSISTANCE MONIES IDENTIFIED IN PART III ARE DISBURSED DIRECTLY TO THE VENDOR OR TO THE PATIENT AFTER APPROPRIATE SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS HAVE BEEN PROVIDED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The Financial Aid Office and Business Office operate together to ensure grants are used for educational purposes. Grants are applied to students' accounts by the Business Office after the grants are approved and disbursed by the Financial Aid Office.

THE UNIVERSITY HAS A FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WHICH IS CHARGED WITH THE RESPONSIBILITY OF APPLYING SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS, DONOR RESTRICTIONS ON ENDOWMENT INCOME TO BE USED FOR SCHOLARSHIPS AND INTERNAL POLICIES FOR INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS IN RELATION TO ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS.

GRANTS AWARDED TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE UNITED STATES CONSIST OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE UNIVERSITIES' POLICIES AND PROCEDURES AS WELL AS LAWS AND REGULATIONS.

GRANT PROPOSALS ARE REVIEWED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S GRANTMAKING COMMITTEE. IF THE PROPOSAL MEETS THE GRANT GUIDELINES THE COMMITTEE DECIDES ON WHETHER TO FUND THE PROJECT. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO THE STUDENTS BASED ON DIFFERENT CRITERIA. THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL POLICIES AND REGULATIONS OF FEDERAL AID PROGRAMS WHEN IT AWARDS FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS. THE UNIVERSITY REQUIRES THE GRANTEE ORGANIZATIONS TO SUBMIT REPORTS TO SUPPORT THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS.

THE UNIVERSITY'S USE OF GRANT FUNDS IS TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL AID TO OUR STUDENTS. WE MONITOR THE USE OF THESE UNIVERSITY FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH ESTABLISHED LEVELS OF AWARDS BASED ON A STUDENT'S MERIT CLASSIFICATION AND ON AN ANNUAL BUDGET. THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL REGULATIONS RELATIVE TO THE AWARDING OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE WHICH IS MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS ALL RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS TO DETERMINE BOTH INITIAL AND CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY BASED UPON THE CRITERIA FOR THE TYPE OF AWARD. VARIOUS CRITERIA MAY INCLUDE, BUT IS NOT LIMITED TO, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL NEED, OR OTHER CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY DONORS OF SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS.

Disbursements in furtherance of the institution's exempt programs are made in accordance with procedures or subject to conditions established by the Institution's governing board designed to ensure that individuals and organizations receiving disbursements from the institution in furtherance of its exempt purpose are adequately investigated to insure that they are qualifying recipients. Students receiving scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy by the institution on the basis of criteria such as academic achievement (fellowships) and financial need (scholarships and fellowships).

Higher Education Emergency Relief Fund In Fiscal Year 2020, Amherst College was awarded $784,291 from the Higher Education Emergency Relief Fund (HEERF). The funds were used for emergency financial aid grants to students under the 18004(A)(1) Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act). The college disbursed the funds to students to assist the students in their transition to remote learning.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: ALL GRANT RECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SATISFACTORILY FILL OUT A PRE-GRANT REQUEST APPLICATION CONFIRMING THE INTENDED USE OF THE FUNDS FOR CHARITABLE PURPOSES CONSISTENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S MISSION. THE GRANTEE ALSO ACKNOWLEDGES IN WRITING THEREIN THE REQUIREMENT THAT ALL FUNDS BE USED FOR SUCH PURPOSES, PERIODIC REPORTING ON EXPENDITURES, AND THAT FUNDS WILL NEED TO BE RETURNED TO GRANTOR IF NOT USED OR TO BE USED IN FURTHERANCE OF THE CHARITABLE PURPOSE. THESE PROVISIONS OF THE APPLICATION COINCIDE WITH THE PRIVATE FOUNDATION EXPENDITURE RESPONSIBILITY REQUIREMENTS OF IRS REGULATIONS. GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS ARE ALL SCHOLARSHIPS MONITORED AS FOLLOWS: "FINANCIAL NEED" IS THE BASIS FOR ASSIGNING MOST INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP, BASED ON ANALYSIS OF FAMILY FINANCES FOR TUITION AFFORDABILITY. SOME INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP IS BASED ON INTERN WORK EXCHANGE SOME INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP IS BASED ON MERIT ASSIGNED FOR DIFFERENT PURPOSES FOR DIFFERENT SCHOLARSHIPS, FOR INSTANCE, A DONOR MAY SPECIFY SOME CRITERIA FOR SOME SPECIFIC DONATED SCHOLARSHIP.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships and stipends are available to undergraduate students and graduate students through the admissions process. Once awarded, depending on the type of aid, payment is credited to either the student account or directly to the student. All payments are monitored and approved by the Financial Services department before payment is applied or paid to the student. All students receiving scholarships and stipends have been selected on a non-discriminatory basis. Faculty enrichment grant opportunities are available to full-time and part-time faculty teaching in a degree program. Selections are based on the merit of the proposal and reviewed by members of a selection committee. Payment are monitored by the Dean's office and all payments are approved by the Vice Provost and School Finance department before payment is made.

ST. EDWARD'S UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS USING A TASK FOR ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT, COMPLIANCE AND FUNDS MANAGEMENT, AND ANNUAL INDEPENDENT AUDITS. THE ENROLLMENT COMMITTEE REVIEWS AWARDING AND RENEWAL POLICIES FOR THE UNIVERSITY GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AND ESTABLISHES FRESHMEN AND TRANSFER ENROLLMENT GOALS ALONG WITH THE FINANCIAL AID PACKAGING STRATEGY NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE THESE GOALS. THE COMMITTEE ENGAGES A NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED LEADER IN THE ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT CONSULTING FIELD TO ASSIST IN THE ESTABLISHMENT AND MONITORING OF FRESHMEN AND TRANSFER ENROLLMENT GOALS AND FINANCIAL AID PACKAGING. EACH COMMITTEE MEMBER AND OTHER KEY UNIVERSITY PERSONNEL RECEIVE WEEKLY REPORTS THROUGHOUT THE FINANCIAL AID AWARDING CYCLE. THE TASK FOR ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT IS COMPRISED OF THE PROVOST, VICE PRESIDENT STUDENT AFFAIRS, VICE PRESIDENT FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION, VICE PRESIDENT ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT, VICE PRESIDENT MARKETING AND COMMUNICATIONS, VICE PRESIDENT INSTITUTIONAL EFFECTIVENESS AND PLANNING, ASSOCIATE VICE PRESIDENTS ACADEMIC SERVICES, ASSOCIATE VICE PRESIDENTS ACADEMIC AFFAIRS, ASSOCIATE VICE PRESIDENT ATHLETICS AND THE DIRECTOR OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE AND PROPER FUND MANAGEMENT, THE UNIVERSITY USES AN ENTERPRISE SOFTWARE TO TRACK ALL FUNDING SOURCES FOR SCHOLARSHIPS FROM UNIVERSITY, FEDERAL, STATE, LOCAL AND PRIVATE SOURCES. THE SOFTWARE HAS A COMPREHENSIVE COMPLIANCE AND FUNDS MANAGEMENT MODULE AND ALLOWS STAFF TO ADD ADDITIONAL FUNCTIONALITY AS NECESSARY. THE COMPLIANCE MODULE IDENTIFIES GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP OFFERS THAT FAIL TO MEET AWARDING CRITERIA AND PREVENTS FINANCIAL AID FROM BEING APPLIED TO A STUDENT IF THE STUDENT DOES NOT MEET THE DISBURSING CRITERIA. FINANCIAL AID RECORDS AND UNIVERSITY GENERAL LEDGER RECORDS ARE RECONCILED USING THE FUNDS MANAGEMENT FUNCTION. ADDITIONAL MONITORING IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH DIAGNOSTIC REPORTS BY FINANCIAL AID IDENTIFYING CODES, TYPES OF GRANTS, FORMS OF GRANTS AND INDIVIDUAL FUNDING SOURCES. ANNUAL AUDITS ARE PERFORMED BY AN INDEPENDENT PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM THAT RENDERS AN OPINION AS TO WHETHER FEDERAL AND CERTAIN STATE FUNDED FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS ARE EXERCISED IN COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS AND REGULATIONS GOVERNING SAID PROGRAMS.

PELL GRANT ORIGINATION, DISBURSEMENT AND RECONCILIATION IS THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE DIRECTOR AND ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR. CNS PRODUCES PELL GRANT ORIGINATION AND DISBURSEMENT RECORDS, WHICH ARE SENT VIA EDCONNECT THROUGH THE COMMON ORIGINATION AND DISBURSEMENT (COD) PROCESS. STATEMENT OF ACCOUNTS FILES ARE RECONCILED MONTHLY BETWEEN CNS AND STUDENT ACCOUNTS, COD AND FINANCIAL AID AND BETWEEN FINANCIAL AID AND STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE DIRECTOR & ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE CAL GRANT PROGRAM. THE WEBGRANTS ROSTER FROM THE CALIFORNIA STUDENT AID COMMISSION IS USED TO DETERMINE A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY FOR A CAL GRANT AWARD. RECONCILIATION IS COMPLETED EVERY TERM AFTER PAYMENT TRANSACTIONS ARE REPORTED THROUGH WEBGRANTS ON A STUDENT-BY-STUDENT BASIS. THE DIRECTOR & ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS & SCHOLARSHIPS. INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS & SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS THAT MEET THE SPECIFIC AWARD'S CRITERIA. THE INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS & SCHOLARSHIPS ARE POSTED IN CNS AND BATCHED OVER TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS ONCE PAYMENT HAS BEEN MADE.

The Financial Aid Office maintains a database of all students, their eligibility for grant funds determined through FAFSA, and other analytical procedures, the amount awarded and accepted by each student, and documentation of verifying the data. The College also has a federal awards audit performed each year in addition to the financial statement audit.

A FILE IS CREATED FOR EACH GRANTEE, WHICH CONTAINS THE OFFICIAL INSTITUTIONAL STUDENT INFORMATION RECORD FROM THE FEDERAL PROCESSOR FROM WHICH ELIGIBILITY IS DETERMINED ACCORDING TO FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES FOR THE AWARDING OF FINACIAL ASSISTANCE.

ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO HAVE COMPLETED THE COLLEGE'S ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS AND HAVE REGISTERED FOR CLASSES. SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE A STUDENT TO MAINTAIN A FULL-TIME STATUS THROUGHOUT THE SEMESTER AND ARE AWARDED FOR ONE YEAR, DIVIDED EVENLY BETWEEN THE FALL AND SPRING SEMESTERS. MOST SCHOLARSHIPS ARE RENEWED ANNUALLY AS LONG AS THE STUDENT MEETS THE RENEWAL CRITERIA AND COMPLETES THE FAFSA. MUSIC AND ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE RE-EVALUATION EACH YEAR AND ARE NOT AUTOMATICALLY RENEWED. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED WITH THE UNDERSTANDING THAT A STUDENT WILL COMPLETE THE SEMESTER FOR WHICH THE AWARD IS RECEIVED. A STUDENT MUST BE IN GOOD STANDING AND MAKING SATISFACTORY PROGRESS IN ORDER TO RECEIVE A SCHOLARSHIP.

THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES ADMINISTERS, RECONCILES, AND REPORTS ALL AID TO STUDENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH GRANT AGENCY PROCEDURES. FUNDS ARE VERIFIED, REVIEWED, AND RECONCILED TO ENSURE APPROPRIATE RECORDING.
FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS FOR OLIVET COLLEGE STUDENTS ENROLLED AND ATTENDING CLASSES. ALL RECORDS ARE RETAINED BY THE COLLEGE.

The process of packaging financial aid is the culmination of the complete analysis of student need and the aid administration cycle, the process of preparation for packaging is completed accurately and confidentially to ensure effective use of all aid funds available, as well as fair and equitable treatment to all applicants.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Form 990, Schedule I, Part I, Line 2
ExplntnTxt: MONITORING GRANTS SINCE ITS INCEPTION, MANAGEMENT REVIEWS REQUESTS FOR GRANTS. TOURO UNIVERSITY MONITORS ALL REQUESTS FOR USE OF GRANT FUNDS AGAINST THE SUBMITTED BUDGETS FOR THE RESPECTIVE GRANTS. PRIOR TO SUBMISSION OF REQUESTS FOR REIMBURSEMENT, ADDITIONAL REVIEW OF EXPENDED FUNDS IS PERFORMED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH GRANT AND UNIVERSITY GUIDELINES. STUDENTS ARE AWARDED TUITION DISCOUNTS BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA. THE DISCOUNTS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are awarded to students for tuition services for one-on-one training. The funds are not given directly to the student but are paid directly to the teacher so the organization is certain of the use of the funds. The teacher provides the organization with monthly reports on the child's progress. Tuition assistance is offered to teachers who meet certain eligibility requirements. Eligibility requirements vary depending on the restrictions of the donor and the class.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: By institutional policy, TCU's office of scholarship and financial aid acts as the final approval authority for all financial aid eligibility determination. Each student's award package is reviewed to ensure compliance with applicable regulatory requirements, and in the case of restricted institutional funds, with the donor's intent and wishes. Academic scholarship eligibility is based on a scoring matrix that evaluates an individual student's success using national test scores, high school GPA, and rigor of curriculum. Those who have excelled academically are generally given the largest share of university funded dollars. Institutionally funded need-based financial aid programs are based on eligibility established by use of an Institutional Methodology, with family financial information submitted to the CSS Profile. The financial aid office also works closely with the donor relations division of university advancement to ensure that our donors' wishes are met when matching funds to students. All donors of endowed awards are provided with a "scholarship agreement" outlining the university's understanding of the donor's intent. These agreements must be approved by both the director of financial aid, and the vice-chancellor for advancement, to ensure that the university has the capability to identify appropriate recipients. In addition to institutionally funded grants and scholarships, TCU manages and accepts fiduciary responsibility for a variety of federal and state funded financial aid programs. Eligibility for all federal and state funded financial aid is based solely on the results of the FAFSA, using required Federal Methodology. Prior to disbursement, each recipient must pass a variety of edit checks, or "disbursement rules" to ensure that the student is enrolled in classes and has submitted all required documentation needed to satisfy program eligibility. After disbursement, student aid recipients are reviewed at the end of the 100% tuition refund period for a final enrollment status determination. Students who received aid based on projected full-time enrollment, but who have dropped below 12 credit hours, are subject to an adjustment of their aid package. At the end of the 25%, and final refund period, students are again reviewed and subject to aid adjustment based on final costs for the term. Aid recipients are monitored on a regular basis throughout the academic year. Files are reviewed weekly to identify updated FAFSA and Profile applications, and adjustments are made when required. Reports are submitted to the Texas higher education coordinating board periodically for review of state aid recipients, and the university is subject to periodic audits and reviews from both entities. Academic success is the ultimate goal of all aid programs, and satisfactory academic progress is reviewed at the end of each term. At a minimum, full-time students are required to complete at least 75% of attempted hours and obtain a 2.00 GPA to meet renewal requirements. Most TCU funded awards require a minimum GPA of 2.50. Academic scholarships require a 3.25 GPA. Once posted to student accounts, the office of student financial services also monitors award amounts in relation to specific charges. Award amounts that appear to be out of norm are referred back to the financial aid office for review.

SCHEDULE I, PART II - THE UNIVERSITY IN ITS EFFORTS TO BE A RESPONSIVE, PRODUCTIVE MEMBER OF ITS LOCAL COMMUNITIES PROVIDES GRANTS AND DONATIONS TO NONPROFITS, SOCIAL SERVICE AGENCIES, AND INITIATIVES. THESE RESOURCES ARE AIMED TO ORGANIZATIONS WHOSE MISSIONS FOCUS ON EDUCATION, THE SERVICE OF MILITARY FAMILIES, ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY, AND PROVIDING ACCESS TO RESOURCES FOR MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES. THE UNIVERSITY'S COMMUNITY RELATIONS STAFF MEETS WITH THESE LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS TO UNDERSTAND WHAT SUPPORT IS WARRANTED, AND THE APPROPRIATE SIZE OF THESE DISTRIBUTIONS. SCHEDULE I, PART III - THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS THROUGH THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS THE APPROPRIATENESS OF THE AWARDS AND THESE AMOUNTS ARE APPLIED TO EACH STUDENT'S ACCOUNT.

THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ISSUES AND MONITORS STUDENT FINANCIAL AID AWARDS. THE FINANCE DIVISION MONITORS THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND DISCOUNTS REFLECTED ON STUDENT BILLING. STUDENT AID IS AWARDED ACCORDING TO THE COLLEGE'S PROCEDURES. STUDENT AID IS AWARDED BASED ON MEETING ESTABLISHED CRITERIA WHICH INCLUDE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND FINANCIAL NEED.

The University receives funds from the U.S. Department of Education for several student financial assistance programs, including the Federal Pell Grant Program, Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant Program, Federal Work-Study Program, Federal Direct Lending, and the Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education Grant Program. The University also receives various state funding from Illinois, which includes the Illinois Monetary Assistance Program (MAP). The university uses the FAFSA (federal form) to apply federal aid. State aid is provided by student per the state. It uses institutional policy to apply institutional funds.
Student financial aid is credited to the individual student accounts and their balances are monitored by staff in the Business Office.

The school awards athletic, academic, and merit-based scholarships. Records related to scholarship eligibility and awards are maintained. Scholarship funds are tied directly to student accounts and no cash changes hands.

A FILE IS CREATED FOR EACH GRANTEE. WE DETERMINE EACH STUDENT'S DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED BASED ON THEIR COST OF ATTENDANCE MINUS EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION ACCORDING TO THE INSTITUTIONAL STUDENT INFORMATION RECORD FROM THE FEDERAL PROCESSOR. WE ATTEMPT TO MEET EACH STUDENT'S DEMONSTRATED NEED WITH A COMBINATION OF MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS, NEED-BASED GRANTS, FEDERAL COLLEGE WORK-STUDY, AND STUDENT LOANS. FINANCIAL AID MAY BE AWARDED FROM FEDERAL, STATE, INSTITUTIONAL, AND PRIVATE SOURCES. WE MONITOR AND MAINTAIN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID POLICIES AND PROCEDURES. IN ADDITION, THE COLLEGE MONITORS AND MAINTAINS SEPARATE FUND ACCOUNTS FOR EACH AWARD CATEGORY AND PROVIDES THE NECESSARY REPORTS TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES.
STUDENTS SEEKING FINANCIAL AID MUST FILE A FAFSA TO DETERMINE THEIR ELIGIBILITY AND NEED FOR GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE

ASSISTANCE IS GIVEN TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE FORM OF CREDITS TOWARD THE COST OF TUITION, AND A RECORD OF THE ASSISTANCE PROVIDED IS RECORDED IN SEPARATE ACCOUNTS MAINTAINED FOR EACH STUDENT/RECIPIENT. IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE INSTITUTION'S BUDGET PROCESS, EACH SCHOOL DETERMINES SCHOLARSHIP SPENDING FOR THE YEAR. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS FINANCIAL AID TO APPLICANTS AT EACH SCHOOL ACCORDING TO THE CRITERIA ESTABLISHED FOR EACH AWARD TYPE. THROUGHOUT THE YEAR, THE BUSINESS OFFICE AND FINANCIAL AID OFFICE COMMUNICATE ABOUT AND RECONCILE DISBURSEMENTS. THE INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT DEPARTMENT PROVIDES ANNUAL REPORTS TO THE DONORS REGARDING THE USE OF DONOR-CONTRIBUTED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART III, EMERGENCY GRANTS TO STUDENTS:
ExplntnTxt: EMERGENCY GRANTS TO STUDENTS REPRESENTS THE HIGHER EDUCATION RELIEF FUNDING PROVIDED BY THE CARES ACT FOR DIRECT DISTRIBUTION TO STUDENTS.

Funds are given and monitored by the mission trip teams that are sent to work with Del Camino each year. The funds are specifically used for the work done during the mission trips. The University's Admissions team monitors the use of funds. Funds given to World Leaders Forum, an affiliated organization, shares information regarding finances, operations, etc. Grants and aid are tracked in the accounting system in a temporarily restricted fund or reimbursed according to a qualified reimbursement policy. An audit of funds granted is conducted when deemed necessary. Grants and aid are applied directly to student accounts.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GENERALLY APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNT BALANCES THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S BURSAR'S OFFICE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Grants and Other Assistance to Individuals in the United States: Scholarships and fellowships that are awarded to students are paid through the students' accounts, the Payroll Office, and/or Accounts Payable Office and are administered based upon merit and/or need. Baylor's Financial Aid Office reviews the students' cumulative grade point averages every year and awards/reviews academic scholarships and fellowships if the required grade point average level is satisfied. Scholarships for financial need are awarded annually based upon the need criterion/level established or maintained per the completed Application for Federal Student Aid. The scholarship awards that are included in the cost of attendance are reviewed so as not to exceed the cost of a student to attend the University. Scholarships and/or fellowships are also awarded to cover student emergency situations. Students must complete an application describing the emergency situation. The University reviews each application to determine if such scholarships/fellowships will be awarded. Travel Grants - Travel grants are awarded to students to offset travel expenses used for educational purposes such as attending a conference, presenting a paper, etc. The awarding of travel grants is based upon an application process and meeting a set of criteria that establish the benefits to the students' educational endeavors. Research Grants - The Office of the Vice Provost for Research (OVPR) publishes guidelines for each of the internal grant programs that provide the general conditions of the award, as well as guidance on the expenses that may be charged to the award. Each grant is set up as a separate project in the University's financial system based on the award amount and budget categories approved by the OVPR. The financial system provides real time access to a Budget Summary Report for the project that provides a comparison of budgeted expenditures to cumulative actual expenditures by expenditure category. This report can be accessed by the Project Manager and others with administrative and financial oversight responsibilities. Expenditure transactions under internal grant programs are subject to internal controls for approval and processing similar to other University expenditure transactions. The system does not allow expenditures to be processed in excess of or outside of the approved budget categories. Student Awards - These awards are provided to students for winning educational competitions. The purpose of the competitions is to further the education of students. Grants and Other Assistance to Governments and Organizations in the United States - The University enters into a contract with the grant recipient that describes the recipient's responsibilities for the use of the grant funds. Under the terms of the contract, recipients are required to submit quarterly and final written progress reports to the principal investigator ("PI") or project director for the grant, and funds are paid to the recipient on a cost reimbursable basis. When the grant recipient submits an invoice for reimbursement, the PI reviews the invoice to ensure the expenditures are consistent with the established budget and with the work completed to date, prior to approving the amount for payment. Grant recipients subject to the U.S. Office of Management and Budget Circular A-133 Audits of States, Local Governments, and Non-Profit Organizations are also required to provide certification of their compliance with the financial audit requirements of those guidelines prior to receiving funds. Thereafter, the University requires an annual certification of continuing compliance and a copy of their most recent audit report. If any of the above processes indicate an area of concern, site visits may be conducted by the University to review the programmatic and/or financial records. Charitable organizations that receive contributions from the University are carefully selected and must be approved through the Chief of Staff to the President & Vice President for Board Relations. Student organizations that are provided University grants must complete an application describing the need for the grant. University contributions must support the University's interest and be consistent with the University's core values.

GENEVA COLLEGE AWARDS GRANTS BASED UPON THE FOLLOWING: THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS BASED ON MERIT AND FINANCIAL NEED. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND BUSINESS OFFICE MAINTAIN RECORDS ON WHAT STUDENTS ARE AWARDED, AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE HAS SPECIFIC CRITERIA THAT MUST BE FOLLOWED IN AWARDING AID TO STUDENTS. THE CRITERIA FOR AWARDING AID IS DOCUMENTED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE INSTITUTION'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENTS, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

GRANTS (FEDERAL/STATE) PASSED THROUGH TO STUDENTS ARE MONITORED USING OUR INTERNAL APPLICATION (POWERFAIDS), THE STATE (PHEAA) AND FEDERAL (COD-COMMON ORIGINATION AND DISBURSEMENT) ELECTRONIC SYSTEMS. A VALIDATION OF RECORDS AMONG ALL THREE SYSTEMS IS CONDUCTED PERIODICALLY THROUGHOUT THE ACADEMIC YEAR AND FOR SEMESTER END RECONCILIATIONS. THOSE SYSTEMS VERIFY THE CRITERIA FOR THE GRANTS HAVE BEEN MET AND THE DOLLAR AMOUNTS RECEIVED HAVE BEEN DISTRIBUTED APPROPRIATELY.

THE UNIVERSITY DETERMINES THE ELIGIBILITY FOR EACH STUDENT'S NEEDS AND THE AWARDS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE STUDENT'S CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY TO RECEIVE THE ASSISTANCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: STUDENTS ELIGIBILITY IS MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND AUDITED ANNUALLY BY THE A133 AUDIT.

THE COLLEGE FIRST INSPECTS CHARGES TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE APPROPRIATE AND ALLOWABLE. THIS INCLUDES CHECKING CLERICAL ACCURACY, REVIEWING BALANCES, AND CHECKING COMPLIANCE WTIH APPLICABLE AGENCY AND FEDERAL GUIDELINES. THE COLLEGE ALSO MAKES SURE THAT THE EXPENSE FALLS WITHIN THE REQUIRED CATEGORY AND BUDGETARY AMOUNT. THIS INCLUDES REVIEWING EXPENSE CATEGORIES, REBUDGETING OR TRANSFERRING EXPENSES AS NEEDED, AND DETERMINING IF THE AWARD WILL BE UNDERSPENT AT THE END OF THE BUDGET OR GRANT PERIOD.

ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AS EITHER NEED-BASED OR MERIT-BASED AWARDS. TO AWARD OR ADMINISTER NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS, THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID FOLLOWS FEDERAL GUIDELINES STARTING WITH THE EVALUATION OF EACH STUDENT FOR NEED-BASED ON FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) & NEED-ACCESS REPORTS. MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BY COMMITTEES ESTABLISHED BY THE DEAN OF THE SCHOOL. ONCE AWARDEES ARE CHOSEN, THE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED THROUGH THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID. ELIGIBILITY FOR EACH ACADEMIC YEAR (SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND CURRENT ENROLLMENT) IS VERIFIED BY THE DIRECTOR PRIOR TO INITIAL DISBURSEMENT OF ANNUAL SCHOLARSHIPS AND ELIGIBILITY IS VERIFIED AGAIN FOR THE JANUARY TERM BEFORE SECOND TERM DISBURSEMENTS ARE MADE. FOR OTHER GRANT MAKING ACTIVITIES, THE SCHOOL REVIEWS ALL INVOICES AND OTHER REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION FOR ACCURACY, APPROPRIATENESS OF THE EXPENDITURES IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE AWARD DOCUMENTS, ANY APPLICABLE RESTRICTIONS, AND TIMELINESS OF SUBMISSION.
STUDENT FINANCIAL AID APPLICATIONS ARE REVIEWED ANNUALLY IN ORDER TO ENSURE GRANT FUNDS ARE AWARDED APPROPRIATELY BASED ON THE INDIVIDUAL AWARD CRITERIA.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Student aid is based on academic achievement, financial need and other similar standards. The College evaluates student eligibility at the end of each semester for the following term and also before disbursement of financial aid.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 2 - PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: STUDENTS ARE AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON AN EVALUATION OF NEED AND ELIGIBILITY FOR SPECIFIC AWARDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH ANY DONOR STIPULATIONS. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT IS RESONSIBLE FOR MAKING SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS AND FOR MONITORING ONGOING ELIGIBILITY (E.G. MAINTENANCE OF SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS.)

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part III PRIZES AND AWARDS
ExplntnTxt: PRIZES AND AWARDS REFLECT PRIZES AND AWARDS EXTENDED TO NON-EMPLOYEES IN RECOGNITION OF AN ACCOMPLISHMENT, ACTIVITY, OR EVENT. PRIZES AND AWARDS GIVEN TO EMPLOYEES ARE INCLUDED AS COMPENSATION AND REPORTED ON AN EMPLOYEE'S FORM W-2.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Explanation: Grants given to support of charitable community organizations. Such grants are extended only for charitable purposes to organizations that are exempt under Code Section 501(c)(3). After qualifications for the grant are met and the grant is disbursed to the charitable organization there is no subsequent monitoring by the University. Grants or other assistance are awarded to organizations or entities in the U.S. pursuant to the University policies and procedures for all grant subawards. Such subawards are monitored through the University's office for Sponsored Research (OSR) and the University's Office of Accounting Services for Research and Sponsored Programs (ASRSP). All subaward documentation including purchase orders, related charges and invoices are reviewed and monitored by ASRSP and confirmed with the principal investigator. The principal investigator must certify that the subaward costs are in accordance with the Office of Management and Budget's (OMB) Uniform Guidance (Uniform Administrative Requirements, Cost Principles, and Audit Requirements); also, ASRSP requests and collects audit reports from subaward recipients to monitor compliance, as required by the Uniform Guidance. If the information is not furnished to ASRSP, payment may be withheld.
SCHOLARSHIPS AND DISCOUNTS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE POSTED DIRECTLY TO EACH STUDENTS ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE SUBSIDIARY ACCOUNT

Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 - All Federal financial aid administered by Barnard College is based on demonstrated financial need as determined by the Federal Methodology formula. However, institutional aid is determined using a Barnard Need Analysis formula which takes into consideration all sources of income and all assets. Barnard does not provide merit scholarships. The College believes that the primary responsibility for financing educational cost rests with each student's family, and all college aid is supplementary to family resources. Once need has been established, Barnard meets the need of all eligible students with a combination of grants, loans and employment opportunities. A student who is admitted to Barnard with financial aid cannot be guaranteed college grants for future years. Awards are for one academic year only. A student can receive Barnard aid for a maximum of eight semesters. Each semester a student is enrolled is counted towards the eight semesters of eligibility whether or not aid was received. No financial aid is given for summer study. If a student has room in her academic year financial aid package and has not already borrowed the maximum loans, these funds may be borrowed during the academic year to be used for classes the following semester. For financial statement purposes, the Pell grant awards of $1,889,707 are excluded.

FOR INDIVIDUAL RECIPIENTS OF GRANTS, ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE AND DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED ARE USED TO DETERMINE EACH STUDENT'S FINANCIAL AID. THE FINANCIAL AID CONSISTS OF ANY COMBINATION OF GRANTS AND LOANS AND ARE REVIEWED EACH YEAR BASED ON A STUDENT'S ACADEMIC RECORD AND/OR DEMONSTRATED NEED. THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID, WHICH HELPS TO ESTABLISH A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED, SERVES AS THE APPLICATION FOR TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS. SIMMONS UNIVERSITY ALSO PASSES GRANTS THROUGH TO OTHER SECTION 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATIONS THAT ARE SUBRECIPIENTS OF GRANT FUNDS.
ALL FINANCIAL AID THAT IS AWARDED IS CREDITED TO THE TUITION BILLING FOR THE STUDENT. ALL AID IS USED TO REDUCE THE TUITION PAYABLE.
A SUBAWARD IS AN AWARD OF FINANCIAL SUPPORT FROM THE UNIVERSITY TO A QUALIFIED THIRD PARTY PRIMARILY TO PERFORM RESEARCH AND OTHER RELATED PROGRAMMATIC EFFORTS UNDER A SPONSORED RESEARCH PROJECT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part III COLUMN B - NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS
ExplntnTxt: THE AMOUNTS REPORTED IN PART III REPRESENT AN ESTIMATE OF TOTAL AWARDS FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2020 BASED ON INFORMATION PROVIDED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S UNDERGRADUATE, GRADUATE AND PROFESSIONAL SCHOOLS. SOME STUDENTS RECEIVED MORE THAN ONE AWARD DURING THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2020.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part II, Line 1 COLUMN H - PURPOSE OF GRANT OR ASSISTANCE
ExplntnTxt: SUBAWARDS - SPONSORED RESEARCH

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: WITH RESPECT TO SPONSORED PROJECT ACTIVITY SUBCONTRACTED TO OTHER ENTITIES, THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICY AND PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING SUB RECIPIENT AWARDS ("SUBaWARDS") ARE INTENDED TO ESTABLISH APPROPRIATE AND EFFECTIVE MECHANISMS TO PROMOTE COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND NON-FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS AND CONTRACTUAL ARRANGEMENTS, INCLUDING THE PROPER MONITORING AND STEWARDSHIP OF AWARDED FUNDS. PROPER MONITORING OF A SUBAWARD ENSURES THAT AWARDED FUNDS ARE USED FOR AUTHORIZED PURPOSES, PERFORMANCE GOALS ARE MET AND THE SUB RECIPIENT IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF THE SUB RECIPIENT AGREEMENT. SUB RECIPIENT MONITORING PROCEDURES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES: A FORMAL PRE-QUALIFICATION PROCESS FOR SUB RECIPIENTS, PRE-AWARD AND POST-AWARD MONITORING OF SUB RECIPIENTS TO REVIEW THE FINANCIAL STATUS AND MANAGEMENT CONTROLS, COMPLIANCE CERTIFICATIONS, REVIEW OF COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS RELATIVE TO THE USE OF HUMAN SUBJECTS AND ANIMALS, IDENTIFICATION AND REPORTING OF ANY CONFLICT OF INTEREST WITH A SUB RECIPIENT ENTITY, AND A REVIEW OF PERTINENT OTHER ORGANIZATION INFORMATION. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THESE PROCEDURES, THE UNIVERSITY REVIEWS THE SUB RECIPIENT'S ADMINISTRATION, FINANCIAL STATEMENTS, BILLINGS, SCIENTIFIC PROGRESS, TECHNICAL REPORTS, AND DELIVERABLES OF AN ACTIVE SUBAWARD REGULARLY AND CONDUCTS ON-GOING RISK ASSESSMENTS AS WELL AS QUARTERLY QUALITY ASSURANCE REVIEWS ON RANDOMLY SELECTED SUBAWARDS. IN ADDITION TO A MONTHLY DEPARTMENTAL REVIEW, THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS A SUB RECIPIENT'S COMPLIANCE WITH THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF THE SUBAWARD ANNUALLY AND UPON CLOSEOUT OF THE SUB RECIPIENT AGREEMENT. IF ANY OF THESE MONITORING PROCEDURES RESULT IN FINDINGS, THE UNIVERSITY WILL TAKE CORRECTIVE ACTION AS NECESSARY. THE PROCEDURES SERVE TO ENSURE THAT THE SUBAWARD FUNDS ARE USED FOR PROPER PURPOSES AND NOT DIVERTED FROM THEIR INTENDED USE.
THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS FINANCIAL AID PRIMARILY BASED UPON ACADEMIC MERIT. THE FUNDS ARE AWARDED VIA ADHERENCE TO A MATRIX WHICH DETERMINES THE AMOUNTS BASED UPON GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND SAT SCORES.
The use of grant funds is monitored through the student financial aid and billing process.

Budgeted amounts are awarded to eligible students who apply for financial aid (selected by committee or using packaging rules). Awarded students are checked to ensure that they are still eligible to receive these funds during the course of the academic year. The scholarships are applied directly to each student's account.

Scholarships and awards are awarded according to scholarship protocols and are continually monitored for satisfactory progress. These scholarships are applied directly to each student's account at the College. Sponsorships are part of a cross collaboration with other colleges and universities in West Michigan. As part of the collaboration, Kuyper is able to monitor the use of the funds to ensure they are used for the intended purpose.
THE COLLEGE PROVIDES ONGOING OVERSIGHT AND MONITORING TO ASSURE THE ACHIEVEMENT OF THE INTENDED PURPOSES AND TIMELY EXPENDITURES OF GRANT FUNDS.

WHEN DETERMINING THE AMOUNT OF FINANCIAL AID A STUDENT WILL RECEIVE, THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE FIRST CALCULATES HOW MUCH THE STUDENT'S FAMILY CAN REASONABLY AFFORD. THIS CALCULATION RELIES ON TWO PRIMARY SOURCES OF INFORMATION: 1) A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA); AND 2) A FINANCIAL AID PROFILE; BOTH OF WHICH ARE COMPLETED BY THE FAMILY. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS A FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE THAT FILLS THE GAP BETWEEN THE CALCULATED AMOUNT THE STUDENT'S FAMILY CAN REASONABLY AFFORD AND THE COST OF ATTENDING MACALESTER COLLEGE. SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: THE COLLEGE AWARDS SMALL GRANTS TO NEIGHBORHOOD ORGANIZATIONS WORKING TO MAKE OUR NEIGHBORHOOD A VIBRANT PLACE TO LIVE, AND TO LOCAL NEIGHBORHOOD COUNCILS COMMITTED TO AREA LIVABILITY ISSUES. GRANT RECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A REPORT DESCRIBING USE OF GRANT FUNDS AT LEAST ANNUALLY OR AT THE CLOSE OF A SPECIFIC PROJECT. THE COLLEGE ALSO MAKES SUBAWARDS FROM GRANT FUNDS TO ORGANIZATIONS THAT AID IN THE RESEARCH BEING CONDUCTED. SUBRECIPIENTS MUST SUBMIT DETAILED REPORTS OF EXPENDITURES BEFORE MACALESTER WILL REIMBURSE THEM.

THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS TO ENSURE DIRECT LOANS ARE AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID REGULATIONS OR DONOR RESTRICTIONS FOR EXTERNALLY FUNDED SCHOLARSHIPS OR COLLEGE CRITERIA FOR INTERNALLY FUNDED SCHOLARSHIPS.

PROCEDURES TO MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. All Federal Title IV funds received by Bryant University are managed in strict compliance with all requirements set forth in the Program Participation Agreement, a formal agreement between Bryant University and the U.S. Department of Education. The Program Participation Agreement is personally endorsed by both the Chief Executive Officer of Bryant University and the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Education. Compliance with all Title IV requirements is monitored by the Director of Financial Aid with the assistance of four (exempt) professional financial aid administrators and three (non-exempt) support staff members. Compliance capability is greatly enhanced through the use of the Banner integrated management information system and its effective interface with other Department of Education systems. The University provides assistance for community support to various organizations through their fundraising events. In the current year, no organization received over $5,000 from the University in this capacity.

GRANT FUNDS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. USAGE IS MONITORED BY VIRTUE OF DIRECT ACCOUNT POSTING. ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF THE GRANTS IS DETERMINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

The Colleges of Law provides scholarships to new and continuing students. These scholarships are dependent upon factors such as alumni recommendations, academic standing, and other criteria related to admission/participation in the program. The Colleges of Law maintains records of the scholarship award amounts, evidence of good academic standing and criteria for scholarship selection.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The majority of grants and assistance provided by the university are in the form of scholarships and financial aid to offset the cost of tuition, room and board for its students. These funds are awarded through the university's financial aid office based on a combination of merit and need and are disbursed directly to the student's billing account with the university.

THE SCHOLARSHIP GRANTS IN SCHEDULE I ARE MONITORED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID RULES AND THE AMOUNT OF AID THAT INDIVIDUALS ARE SUPPOSED TO RECEIVE. THE DISCOUNTS AND EXPENDITURES ARE MONITORED BY AGREEMENTS WITH CERTAIN GROUPS AND IF THE STUDENT IS PART OF THAT COHORT, THEY RECEIVE A DISCOUNTED RATE ON TUITION, WHICH IN EFFECT TRANSLATES TO AID.
SCHOLARSHIPS AND DISCOUNTS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND FINANCIAL NEED, AND ARE GIVEN TO CURRENT SCHOLARS. THEY ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE OFFICES OF ADMISSIONS AND STUDENT SERVICES.

LIPSCOMB UNIVERSITY HAS AN ANNUAL AUDIT OF ITS FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND AN ANNUAL AUDIT OF ITS FINANCIAL AID AWARDING PROCESS (CALLED THE OMB CIRCULAR A-133 AUDIT). IN ADDITION, FINANCIAL AID COUNSELORS ATTEND CONFERENCES AND TRAINING SESSIONS ON FINANCIAL AID AWARDING POLICIES, PROCEDURES, AND CONTROLS.

The Office of Financial Aid maintain records to substantiate the amount of the grants or assistance disbursed to students, the students' eligibility for the grants or assistance, and the selection criteria used to award the grants or assistance.

CUI awards scholarships and financial aid to students based on financial need, talent, and/or academic merit and programs. Federal and State programs are awarded based on respective program requirements. Federal and State programs are compliance tested yearly in conjunction with the independent audit and auditor reports / newsletters are submitted to all organizations as required by the programs.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS: FINANCIAL AID GUIDELINES ARE UTILIZED TO DETERMINE THE QUALIFICATIONS OF EACH RECIPIENT. THE GUIDELINES ARE PUBLISHED IN CONVERSE COLLEGE'S ACADEMIC CATALOG AND COMPLY WITH ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS PUBLISHED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE. ANNUAL COMPLIANCE AUDITS ARE COMPLETED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM. THE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. FOR CARES EMERGENCY GRANT AWARDS, FOR ELIGIBLE STUDENTS, THE INDIVIDUAL GRANT AMOUNT RELATED TO THE DISRUPTION BECAUSE OF CORONAVIRUS. THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION PROVIDED GUIDANCE BASED UPON THE CARES ACT LEGISLATION THAT CONVERSE WAS REQUIRED TO FOLLOW WHEN DISTRIBUTING THE FUNDS. THE DISBURSEMENTS TO INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION FROM THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT WERE CALCULATED BASED ON ENROLLMENT AND THE ENROLLMENT OF STUDENTS ELIGIBLE FOR PELL GRANT FUNDS. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THOSE GUIDELINES, CONVERSE DISTRIBUTED THE FUNDS BY NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC) ESTABLISHED ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). GRANTS WERE DETERMINED BASED ON EFC, RESIDENTIAL STATUS, AND THE STUDENT'S STATUS AT THE COLLEGE.
Committee sets criteria and to provide oversight.
All assistance is in the form of grants and scholarships. These funds are applied directly to the student's account.

Simpson University awards financial aid grants to students in accordance with the University's institutional financial aid policies. All scholarships are awarded to current students of the institution, thus enabling the institution to track their academic performance and use of all scholarship funds. Scholarships funds are directly applied to the student accounts, with no cash changing hands.

GRANTS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS. THESE FUNDS ARE THEN USED FOR TUITION AND OTHER EXPENSES RELATED TO EDUCATION (BOOKS, LAB EQUIPMENT, ETC). FUNDS ARE GENERALLY NOT ACTUALLY RELEASED TO THE STUDENTS, BUT ARE USED TO OFFSET TUITION COSTS BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.
OF THIS AMOUNT, $48,600 ARE FOR AWARDS THAT ARE RELEASED DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS.

THE SCHOOL PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON MERIT AND FINANCIAL AID BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED. ANNUALLY, ALL VICE PRESIDENTS OF FINANCE WORK WITH THE REGIONAL ENROLLMENT DIRECTORS TO DETERMINE THE BUDGETS AVAILABLE FOR SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID. THOSE BUDGETS ARE APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT AND CFO. ALL STUDENT APPLICATIONS ARE THEN REVIEWED AND AWARDS ARE PROVIDED TO THOSE STUDENTS WHO MEET CERTAIN CRITERIA.
Grants were made only for tax-exempt purposes and were mostly to related organizations.

DISBURSEMENTS TO STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL AID ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH INSTITUTIONAL PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT THOSE RECEIVING AID ARE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS. FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID AND/OR ASSISTANCE FROM GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES IS DISTRIBUTED AND MONITORED IN ACCORDANCE WITH FEDERALLY APPROVED NEED ANALYSIS CRITERIA OR OTHER AGENCY PROVIDED CRITERIA. IN ADDITION TO STUDENT FINANCIAL AID, THE COLLEGE ALSO PROVIDES ASSISTANCE TO ORGANIZATIONS IN SUPPORT OF COMMUNITY GOALS THAT ALIGN WITH THE MISSION OF THE COLLEGE. AS THE COLLEGE IS SELECTIVE IN WHICH ORGANIZATIONS IT SUPPORTS, MONITORING OF THE FUNDS IS NOT A PART OF THE AWARD PROCESS AFTER FUNDING HAS TAKEN PLACE.

A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID IS DETERMINED ON THE BASIS OF THEIR ANNUAL COST OF ATTENDANCE, WHICH IS CALCULATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS, MINUS EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION, WHICH IS DETERMINED IN ACCORDANCE WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS AND UNIVERSITY STANDARDS. IN THE EVENT THAT TOTAL AID AWARDED EXCEEDS DIRECT COSTS (I.E., COSTS THAT ARE BILLED BY THE UNIVERSITY), THE EXCESS FUNDS ARE PROVIDED TO THE STUDENT AND ARE APPLICABLE TO EDUCATIONALLY-RELATED EXPENSES. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT REQUIRE THE STUDENT TO PROVIDE PROOF (E.G., RECEIPTS, CANCELLED CHECKS, ETC.) AS TO HOW THE FUNDS WERE USED.

ALLEN MEMORIAL HOSPITAL CORPORATION MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS ACCORDING TO THE STANDARD FINANCIAL POLICIES OF THE ORGANIZATION AND AS REQUIRED BY THE GRANT OR GRANTOR. THE POLICIES AND PROTOCOLS OF THE FUNDING SOURCE ARE ENFORCED AND MONITORED BY THE ORGANIZATION AND REPORTED AS REQUIRED.
CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL COLORADO RELIES ON THE GOVERNANCE PRACTICES OF THE RECIPIENT EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS TO MONITOR THE USE OF FUNDS AS INTENDED.

ST. LUKE'S METHODIST HOSPITAL REQUIRES EACH RECIPIENT OF THE GRANTS MENTIONED IN PARTS II & III (OTHER THAN ASSISTANCE TO RELATED ORGANIZATIONS IN THE FORM OF WORKING CAPITAL) TO APPLY FOR THE GRANT AND OUTLINES A SERIES OF ELIGIBILITY STANDARDS THAT ARE REQUIRED TO BE MET. ST. LUKE'S METHODIST HOSPITAL THEN REVIEWS THESE APPLICATIONS AND, BASED ON NEED AND ELIGIBILITY, A COMMITTEE MAKES THE FINAL DECISION ON ALL GRANT RECIPIENTS.

COMMUNITY MEDICAL CENTER (CMC) DOES NOT AWARD GRANTS; CMC PROVIDES ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS TO TAX-EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS THAT QUALIFY FOR 501(C)(3) STATUS UNDER THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE, LIMITED 501(C)(4) ORGANIZATIONS BASED ON EXPLICIT CRITERIA, PUBLIC BENEFIT OR NON-EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS WHOSE ACTIVITIES FURTHER THE EXEMPT PURPOSE OF CMC. CMC NOTIFIES THE PUBLIC BENEFIT OR NON-EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS OF THE INTENT AND PURPOSE OF THE CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTION. ORGANIZATIONS SEEKING SUPPORT MUST DEMONSTRATE THAT THEY EFFECTIVELY MEET AN IMPORTANT COMMUNITY HEALTH NEED.

To ensure our grants and scholarships are used for proper purpose the Financial Aid Office performs regular maintenance and reconciliation with our Bursar's Office monitoring that all funds awarded to a particular student are being properly credited to their student account. Any changes or adjustments to original award that affect grant and scholarship funding are documented, saved and then copied to our Bursar's Office. These processes are completed utilizing an automated software system which allows us to generate reports at any time for monitoring and reconciliation purposes. Additionally, we have a yearly audit performed by an outside accounting firm guaranteeing we are staying in compliance with all federal, state, and institutional policies and procedures as well as assuring funding is being used as intended.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The University provides scholarships to students matriculating through its programs. Funds are applied directly to student accounts by the University's Office of Student Accounts in accordance with the applicable terms of the specific grant/scholarship. During the year ended June 30, 2020, the University issued Higher Education Emergency Relief Fund (HEERF) direct awards to students of $417,000.

GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED UPON THE CRITERIA ESTABLISHED WITH EACH GRANT. FINANCIAL AID PERSONNEL MONITOR EACH GRANT ALONG WITH THE TOTAL AID RECEIVED BY EACH STUDENT TO ENSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS AS WELL AS COLLECTIVE AWARDS ARE WITHIN THE GUIDELINES ESTABLISHED BY STATE AND FEDERAL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES.

PIT STAFF (BUSINESS OFFICE, GRANT ADMINISTRATOR, VICE PRESIDENT AND PROVOST) HAVE MONTHLY MEETINGS TO REVIEW GRANT DISBURSEMENTS. THE GRANT ADMINISTRATOR GOES TO CONFERENCES AS SCHEDULED. WHEN THE GRANT IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS, THEN FINANCIAL AID AND STUDENT SERVICES VERIFY STUDENT ELIGIBILITY. THE BUSINESS OFFICE KEEPS COPIES OF ALL DISBURSEMENTS AND PROVIDES COPIES TO GRANT ADMINISTRATORS. THE BUSINESS OFFICE STAFF TRACK ALL SALARIES COVERED BY GRANTS. RECIPIENTS ARE DETERMINED BY STUDENTS APPLYING FOR A SCHOLARSHIP AND THEN THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE MEETS TO REVIEW AND APPROVE ALL SCHOLARSHIPS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 SYRACUSE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED APPROXIMATELY $344 MILLION IN INSTITUTIONAL AID TO UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS IN THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2020. THE AID PROVIDED CONSISTS OF A COMBINATION OF NEED-BASED AND MERIT-BASED GRANTS. STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR THESE FINANCIAL AID AWARDS BY COMPLETING TWO FORMS THAT ESTABLISH ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID: THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE FINANCIAL AID PROFILE; AND THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. THESE ARE STANDARD FORMS USED IN HIGHER EDUCATION FOR THIS PURPOSE. BOTH NEED-BASED AND MERIT-BASED AID PROVIDED TO STUDENTS IS APPLIED BY THE UNIVERSITY DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GENERALLY LIMITED TO THE AMOUNT OF TUITION. STUDENTS REACHING THE "TUITIONARE INELIGIBLE FOR ADDITIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS FROM THE UNIVERSITY. NEED-BASED AID CAN BE USED FOR ALL EDUCATIONAL RELATED EXPENSES IN ADDITION TO TUITION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GRANTS TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART II THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO THE AMERICAN HEART ASSOCIATION, JUVENILE DIABETES RESEARCH FOUNDATION INTERNATIONAL, INDIGENOUS VALUES INITIATIVE, LONGHOUSE COUNCIL OF BOY SCOUTS OF AMERICA AND SUNDANCE INSTITUTE AND RECEIVED ACKNOWLEDGMENT THAT MONIES REPRESENT CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR EACH ORGANIZATION'S EXEMPT PURPOSE.

PART III, COLUMN B THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS WHO RECEIVED SCHOLARSHIPS WAS DERIVED BY QUERYING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT DATABASE IN THE STUDENT RECEIVABLE SYSTEM FOR ACADEMIC TERMS WITHIN THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2020. THE QUERY LOOKED FOR TUITION DISCOUNT (FINANCIAL AID) AND OTHER ASSISTANCE USING THE DEFINITION OF SUCH ITEMS AS REPORTED IN THE UNIVERSITY'S AUDITED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS. THIS PRODUCED A REPORT OF ALL STUDENTS WHO RECEIVED AID. RECOGNIZING THAT A STUDENT COULD BE RECEIVING AID IN MORE THAN ONE ACADEMIC TERM, THE INFORMATION WAS THEN SORTED BY INDIVIDUAL AND THE STUDENT WAS COUNTED ONLY ONCE PER FINANCIAL AID TYPE.

Schedule I, Part III, Line 6 The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act was enacted into law on March 27, 2020 as a $2 Trillion National Economic Rescue Package. Approximately $14B of the funding was reserved for higher education institutions and the students they serve through the higher education emergency relief fund (HEERF). Syracuse University was allocated approximately $9.92M from the Fund, of which $4,061,489 was awarded as emergency financial aid to students during the year ending June 30, 2020.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS:
ExplntnTxt: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 THE COLLEGE HAS DESIGNED AND IMPLEMENTED INTERNAL CONTROLS THAT INCLUDE FINANCIAL REPORTING AS WELL AS INTERNAL CONTROL OVER COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS AND GRANT AGREEMENTS. INCLUDED IN THE INTERNAL CONTROL STRUCTURE IS A COMPREHENSIVE GRANTS AND CONTRACTS POLICY THAT PROVIDES THE ECKERD COLLEGE COMMUNITY GUIDELINES FOR GRANTS RECORDKEEPING, REPORTING AND MANAGEMENT.THE FINANCIAL AID AND BUSINESS OFFICES HAVE PRIMARY ROLES IN THE MONITORING OF GRANT FUNDS WHICH INCLUDES PROCEDURES FOR FINANCIAL REPORTING, FUNDS REQUESTS, INVOICING, REIMBURSEMENTS, PROGRAM ACTIVITY OVERSIGHT, PURCHASES, CLOSE OUT AND POST AWARD COMPLIANCE. THE BUSINESS OFFICE COMMUNICATES DIRECTLY AND FREQUENTLY WITH FACULTY AND STAFF MEMBERS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL COLLEGE POLICIES. THE COLLEGE IS ALSO SUBJECT TO EXTERNAL AUDITS WHICH ARE PERFORMED AT LEAST ANNUALLY.

PART II - THE OFFICE OF THE CHANCELLOR MONITORS ALL FUNDS ALLOCATED TO EXTERNAL ORGANIZATIONS. PART III- THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS THAT ARE ALL APPLIED TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE BALANCES.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS: GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY IS NOT A "GRANTMAKER" PER SE IN THAT ITS FUNDAMENTAL MISSION RELATES TO EDUCATION AND RESEARCH. HOWEVER, IN THE COURSE OF THESE MISSION-RELATED ACTIVITIES, THE UNIVERSITY DOES MAKE PAYMENTS THAT MEET THE CRITERIA FOR "GRANTMAKING" AS DEFINED BY THE INSTRUCTIONS TO SCHEDULE I OF THE FORM 990. THESE PAYMENTS FALL INTO FOUR CATEGORIES: (1) STUDENT FINANCIAL AID - THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BASED EITHER ON FINANCIAL NEED OR ACADEMIC MERIT; THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES (THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE) DETERMINES STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID. VARIOUS ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR MERIT-BASED AID; (2) CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS, WHICH ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICY; (3) SUBAWARDS, WHICH ARE MONITORED BY THE OFFICE OF THE CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER; AND (4) OTHER GRANTS IN SUPPORT OF THE UNIVERSITY'S MISSION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Scholarship Funds, both budgeted and investments, are monitored by the Board of Directors and appointed staff, with dividends being awarded as scholarships by decision of the Financial Aid Office and/or the Scholarship Committee, and distributed through the Business Office.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 ALL GRANTS OR OTHER ASSISTANCE TO DOMESTIC ORGANIZATIONS OR DOMESTIC GOVERNMENTS ARE AUTHORIZED AND INITIATED BY THE PRESIDENTS OFFICE WITH STRICT CONTROLS OVER THE SELECTION AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE FUNDS. ALL SUCH GRANTS WERE MADE TO 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATIONS OR DOMESTIC GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES. FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS, NEED-BASED GRANTS, WORK-STUDY AND STUDENT LOANS. ELIGIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL AID VARIES BASED ON THE CRITERIA OF EACH AWARD. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT SUCH AS HIGH SCHOOL GRADE POINT AVERAGE, SAT OR ACT SCORE AND CLASS RANK, AND/OR EXTRA-CURRICULAR ACTIVITIES AND RECOMMENDATIONS. NEED-BASED GRANTS ARE OFFERED TO STUDENTS WHO COMPLETE A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND WHO, BASED ON THIS INFORMATION, MEET THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE NEED-BASED AID. ALL STUDENTS WHO ARE SELECTED FOR VERIFICATION BY THE CENTRAL PROCESSING SYSTEM (CPS) MUST ALSO SUBMIT VERIFICATION OF THE INFORMATION PROVIDED ON THE FAFSA. NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS INCLUDE THE FEDERAL PELL GRANT AND FEDERAL SUPPLEMENTAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY GRANT (SEOG), STATE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, AND EMMANUEL COLLEGE GRANT AID. IN ADDITION TO NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENTS WHO APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID AND DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED MAY ALSO RECEIVE FEDERAL WORK STUDY AND NEED-BASED FEDERAL AND STATE STUDENT LOANS. THE LOAN PROGRAMS OFFERED BY EMMANUEL COLLEGE ARE THE FEDERAL STAFFORD LOAN, THE FEDERAL PERKINS LOAN AND THE MASSACHUSETTS NO-INTEREST LOAN. PRIOR TO DISBURSING ANY FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR EACH GRANT, SCHOLARSHIP, WORK-PROGRAM OR STUDENT LOAN IS CERTIFIED. TO RECEIVE NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID EACH ACADEMIC YEAR.

Cares Act Higher Education Emergency Relief Fund EMERGENCY STUDENT AID During the year ended June 30, 2020, the College received $1,651,976 from the U.S. government through the Higher Education Emergency Relief Fund (HEERF) as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The College paid students $825,988 for emergency financial aid grants under the 18004(a)(1) Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act). The remaining $825,988 was the institutional share of the HEERF funds and used to fund the Colleges COVID 19 related costs. The HEERF grant proceeds were recognized as government and other private grants revenue.

PSC PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID TO INDIVIDUALS TO ATTEND THE COLLEGE. THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND AID FOR SUCH STUDENTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON NEED AND MERIT AND COVER THE COSTS OF TUITION, ROOM, AND BOARD. THE SCHOLARSHIP AND/OR FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BASED ON INSTITUTIONAL POLICY AND STANDARDS SET FORTH BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND THE STATE OF ARKANSAS. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MONITORS THE COMPLIANCE WITH SUCH REGULATIONS. THE SCHOLARSHIP AND/OR FINANCIAL AID IS APPLIED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT WITH THE COLLEGE AS A REDUCTION IN FEES. AS A RESULT, THE GRANT CAN ONLY BE USED FOR ITS INTENDED PURPOSE (I.E. COST OF ATTENDANCE) AND CANNOT BE DIVERTED FROM THIS USE. FOR CARES EMERGENCY GRANTS, AWARDS WERE BASED ON NEED AND NOT REQUIRED TO BE SPENT BY THE RECIPIENTS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE THAT WOULD REQUIRE MONITORING AFTER THE GRANT FUNDS WERE AWARDED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are awarded to students on the basis of need and merit. The amount of the award is applied directly to the students account. All records and amounts are substantiated in the records of the Financial Aid Office.

Saybrook University provides scholarships to new and continuing students. These scholarships are dependent upon factors such as recommendations, academic standing, and other criteria related to admission/participation in the program. Saybrook University maintains records of the scholarship award amounts, evidence of good academic standing and criteria for scholarship selection.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: USE OF GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE, FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND GRANT COORDINATOR, IF APPLICABLE, TO DETERMINE THAT REQUIRED CRITERIA ARE MET.

THE AWARDING OF FINANCIAL AID STARTS AFTER A STUDENT IS ACCEPTED INTO BLUFFTON UNIVERSITY. THOSE STUDENTS WHO NEED FINANCIAL SUPPORT HAVE TO FILE AN APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. BLUFFTON UNIVERSITY OFFERS UNIVERSITY FUNDS, STATE AND FEDERAL GRANTS AND STUDENT LOANS. NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID GRANTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON THE CALCULATIONS FROM FAFSA AND THE RESULTING FINANCIAL NEED OF THE STUDENTS. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DETERMINED AT THE TIME OF ACCEPTANCE AND BASED OFF OF HIGH SCHOOL GPA AND STANDARDIZED TEST SCORES OR TRANSFERRING GPA.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IS MONITORED THROUGH A GRANT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM.

All Oak Hills Christian College scholarships are monitored by the Financial Aid Office with attention given to the criteria set forth for each award as well as the student's enrollment status. The scholarships are applied directly to the student accounts. Camp scholarship assistance is available for campers whose families are financially unable to send their children to camp. The camper must be registered with a $25 deposit and submit a scholarship request form. The amount of scholarship requested will be applied to the camper's registration fee. A camper may request only one scholarship per calendar year. CIM(MMC) scholarships are awared based upon student need.

The procedures for monitoring the use of grant funds to domestic organizations vary based on the nature of the agreement with the grantee. Organizations operating out of the Muller Chapel (Hillel and Newman Foundation) are subject to oversight by college employees. The college follows the OMB Uniform Guidance with respect to monitoring the use of funds of subrecipients of Federal awards (Planetary Science Institute and Northeastern Illinois University). For grants to all other domestic organizations, the college relegates responsibility for monitoring the use of grant funds to individuals within those organizations. Students must meet the criteria specified in the scholarship program in order to receive the scholarship. For ongoing scholarships, students must continue to meet the criteria in order to be awarded a scholarship in subsequent years.
STUDENT FINANCIAL AID IS MONITORED BY INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES AND A COMMITTEE OF EMPLOYEES WITH RESPONSIBILITY TO ENSURE THE INSTRUCTION GUIDELINES ARE PROPERLY FOLLOWED.

SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO ENROLLED STUDENTS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS TO COVER TUITION AND FEES. GRADE REPORTS ARE GENERATED FOR EACH TERM, AND EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS REVIEWED TO ENSURE THEY ARE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS TO MAINTAIN THEIR GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING. ALSO, FINANCIAL AID RUNS ENROLLMENT REPORTS EACH TERM TO CHECK THE NUMBER OF CREDIT HOURS FOR EACH STUDENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part II Grants and Other Assistance to Domestic Organizations and Domestic Governments
ExplntnTxt: PER SCHEDULE I INSTRUCTIONS, THE UNIVERSITY HAS INCLUDED DONATIONS FROM DONOR ADVISED FUNDS (DAF) THAT EXCEEDED THE MINIMUM REPORTING THRESHOLD. IN TOTAL, THE UNIVERSITY REPORTED 96 IRC 501(C)(3) CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS THAT RECEIVED DONATIONS FROM HARVARD UNIVERSITY THROUGH THESE DAF. AS WITH ANY DAF, DISTRIBUTIONS MADE FROM THE FUND ARE TYPICALLY MADE AT THE REQUEST OF THE DONOR ADVISOR AND MUST BE MADE TO AN IRC 501(C)(3) CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: ALL DISBURSEMENTS MADE BY THIS INSTITUTION IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY AUTHORIZED COMMITTEES OR INDIVIDUALS. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND STUDENT LOANS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY HARVARD'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICES. IN ADDITION, HARVARD UNIVERSITY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE PROGRAMMATIC AND FINANCIAL MONITORING OF ITS SPONSORED RESEARCH AWARD SUBRECIPIENTS. PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS AND PROJECT STAFF PERFORM ONGOING REVIEWS OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES. IN ADDITION, ON AN ANNUAL BASIS, UNIVERSITY RESEARCH ADMINISTRATORS REVIEW ALL ACTIVE SUBCONTRACTS AND INQUIRE FURTHER INTO THOSE THAT ARE DEEMED TO REQUIRE CLOSER SCRUTINY IN LIGHT OF A VARIETY OF ATTRIBUTES. UPON IDENTIFICATION OF SUBRECIPIENTS THAT MANDATE CLOSER SCRUTINY, HARVARD IMPLEMENTS ADDITIONAL MONITORING ACTIONS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH SUBAGREEMENT PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS, AND WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: ST. JOHN'S HOSPITAL PARTICIPATES IN VARIOUS FEDERAL LOAN AND GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE PROGRAMS ARE ADMINISTERED IN ACCORDANCE WITH GUIDELINES ESTABLISHED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, AND THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES. THESE PROGRAMS ARE AUDITED ANNUALLY IN ACCORDANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133 "AUDITS OF INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION AND OTHER NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS".

MIDLAND UNIVERSITY OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

The University awards scholarships to individual students based upon financial need, scholastic ability, and other criteria. Monitoring of each student's enrollment status and GPA occurs throughout the award period to ensure grant criteria are met. No cash changes hands, and funds are directly applied to student accounts. OBU used a hybrid method to award the emergency financial aid funds. An application was provided to all students for them to report emergency costs associated with the campus closure due to Covid-19 in the spring semester. OBU also used the group method to target specific groups of students with similar expenses.

Stipends and research fellowships are funds paid to offset living expenses for trainees while they further their education at Rockefeller. These amounts are not considered salary or wages given in consideration for specific job duties nor are they grants given in anticipation of specific scientific achievements on the individuals parts. There is no restriction on the use of the funds once they are received by the trainees.

ALL GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE THAT ARE PROVIDED BY THOMAS AQUINAS COLLEGE ARE PART OF A NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM THAT ASSISTS STUDENTS WITH THE COST OF TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD. BESIDES GRANTS, THE ONLY OTHER ASSISTANCE OFFERED IS A NEED-BASED EMPLOYMENT PROGRAM. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNT OF THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE, THE GRANTEE'S ELIGIBILITY FOR THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE, AND THE SELECTION CRITERIA USED TO AWARD THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE. ALL GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE ARE CAREFULLY MONITORED BY THOMAS AQUINAS COLLEGE. THE AMOUNTS ARE DISBURSED DIRECTLY INTO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT FOR TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD, AND CONSEQUENTLY, THE COLLEGE HAS FULL CONTROL OVER HOW THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE ARE USED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 2 - Grants and Allocations:
ExplntnTxt: APPROXIMATELY 57 PERCENT OF TRINITY COLLEGE UNDERGRADUATES ARE RECEIVING ASSISTANCE FROM THE COLLEGE, FEDERAL OR STATE FUNDS. GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS THE DISBURSEMENT OF FINANCIAL AID. SCHEDULE I, PART III: THE CASH GRANT INCLUDES CREDITS ON STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

The College follows federal guidelines for determining the financial need of each student. The College Board Profile and the FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid) provides information to determine financial need. Grants and scholarships are awarded based on the demonstrated need of each student. The College has a Town Gown Committee which awards small grants to local community organizations based on submitted proposals. No grants were issued to local organizations in the year ended June 30, 2020 due to the pandemic.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The organization uses congressional methodology from the US Department of Education's need analysis. It assigns student eligibility based on effective family contribution from the Pell Processing Center. All records on packaging as well as awarding are processed through the organization's PowerFAIDS system.

The University's Office of Financial Aid monitors all recipients of scholarship awards to determine both initial and confirming eligibility based on the criteria for each type of award, which may include academic performance, financial need, and criteria established by donors of endowed scholarship funds, etc.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS: SCHOLARSHIPS AND PRIZES ARE AWARDED BASED ON NEED AND MONITORED ANNUALLY BASED ON STUDENTS' ACADEMIC PROFILES AND GUIDELINES AS PROVIDED TO STUDENTS. THESE GUIDELINES ARE ALSO AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS ON THE SKIDMORE COLLEGE WEBSITE.

The financial aid office at Charleston Southern University requires students to complete the Free Application for Federal Student aid (FAFSA) form to determine eligibility for Federal, State, and institutional grants, scholarships and loans. This is an equitable formula that measures all assets consistently. In addition to this form, the institution does require some other guidelines in the event that funds are offered based upon certain academic credentials or performance in a University sponsored activity or athletic event. These credentials are clearly stated in the University catalog and the University website. Enrollment and eligibility are monitored by the University. Scholarships are applied directly to student accounts. No cash changes hands.

MONITORING GRANT FUNDS: GRANT FUNDS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE USED FOR TUITION AND ALLOWABLE EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES. AWARDS ARE BASED ON NEED DETERMINED FROM A FEDERAL FAFSA APPLICATION. GRANT FUNDS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE TUITION AND FEES OF THE AWARDEE AND DO NOT LEAVE POSSESSION OF THE COLLEGE, THEREFORE NO MONITORING IS NECESSARY.

THE MAJORITY OF GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE AWARDED ARE ADMINISTERED ACCORDING TO THE POLICIES OUTLINED BY THE FUNDING SOURCE. TYPICALLY, GRANT MONEY IS RECEIVED BY THE COLLEGE AND IS APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. THE FEDERAL WORK-STUDY PROGRAM DOES ALLOW FUNDS TO BE DISTRIBUTED DIRECTLY TO THE RECIPIENT STUDENT. GIFTS TO ORGANIZATIONS ARE CHARITABLE IN NATURE AND DO NOT REQUIRE FORMAL MONITORING OF THE USE OF FUNDS.

ALL GRANTS ARE AWARDED ONLY AFTER CONFIRMING A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY -CONSISTENT TO ALL GRANT CRITERIA. EACH SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT IS RECONCILED AT THE END OF EACH SEMESTER AND AWARD YEAR TO VERIFY STUDENTS MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY. REPORTS MONITORING GPA, CITIZENSHIP, FEDERAL AND INSTITUTIONAL ELIGIBILITY ARE USED TO AWARD AND ENSURE RECONCILIATION FOR EACH FUND.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO OTHERWISE WOULD NOT BE ABLE TO AFFORD MUSIC INSTRUCTION. AWARDS ARE GENERALLY NOT MORE THAN 50% OF THE STUDENTS TOTAL TUITION (UNLESS THE STUDENT IS PART OF OUR TEEN JAZZ PROGRAM). TEEN JAZZ SCHOLARSHIPS ARE FUNDED BY VARIOUS GRANTS AND AWARDS AND CAN COVER UP TO 100% OF THE TUITION. ALL SCHOLARSHIP STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO FILL OUT A FINANCIAL AID APPLICATION. THIS INCLUDES SUBMITTING THEIR MOST RECENT FEDERAL TAX FORM (1040, 1040A, OR 1040EZ), COPIES OF THE MOST RECENT PAYSTUBS FOR LAST TWO PAY PERIODS, STUDENT EVALUATION FORM FROM EXISTING TEACHERS OR A COPY OF THE STUDENT'S MOST RECENT REPORT CARD (FOR STUDENTS UNDER 18 YEARS), AND AN EXPLANATION OF ANY EXTENUATING CIRCUMSTANCES IF ANY (THIS CAN INCLUDE DISABILITY, SOCIAL SECURITY, ETC.) HARD COPIES OF FINANCIAL AID APPLICATIONS ARE KEPT ON FILE, AND AWARD AMOUNTS ARE RECORDED IN THE SCHOOL'S REGISTRATION SYSTEM FOR STUDENTS ACCEPTING THE SCHOLARSHIP.

THE STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR THE GRANTS AND MEET THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE VARIOUS GRANTS. THE PROCESS BY WHICH EACH GRANT IS AWARDED AND MONITORED IS FORMALIZED IN A POLICY WHICH IS UPDATED BY THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID.
GRANTS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE GIVEN TO STUDENTS ATTENDING THE COLLEGE. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS THE FUNDS THAT ARE GIVEN TO EACH STUDENT.

Scholarships and student aid are monitored through the financial aid office to ensure that all scholarship monies are used for housing, tuition, meals and books. No cash changed hands and funds were directly tied to student accounts.

CARTHAGE COLLEGE OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

TLU FOLLOWS THE RULES AND REGULATIONS IN TERMS OF PROCEDURES PROVIDED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND ALL GRANTING AGENCIES. PRIVATE GRANTS ARE HANDLED BY DEVELOPMENT AND FINANCIAL SERVICES AND ALL REQUIRED REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE TEXAS HIGHER EDUCATION COORDINATING BOARD AND APPROPRIATE AGENCIES. ADDITIONALLY, TLU UNDERGOES AN AUDIT AS SET FORTH IN THE SINGLE AUDIT ACT AND OMB CIRCULAR A-133.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES PAYMENT OF THE GRANTS, EXCEPT FOR HEERF AMOUNTS, TO THE STUDENT AS A CREDIT TO THE STUDENTS' RECEIVABLE ACCOUNTS; THE GRANTS ARE NOT DIRECTLY PAID TO THE STUDENTS. FOR THE GRANT TO BE AVAILABLE TO THE STUDENT, THE COLLEGE MONITORS THE STUDENT'S ENROLLMENT AND THE STUDENT MUST BE ENROLLED AND ACTIVE FOR THE TIME PERIOD THE GRANT IS OFFERED. IF THE STUDENT LEAVES THE PROGRAM EARLY, THE GRANT IS NOT REFUNDED TO THE STUDENT AND THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT IS RATABLY ADJUSTED TO REFLECT THE INCOMPLETE PERIOD. AMOUNTS GRANTED UNDER THE HIGHER EDUCATION EMERGENY RELIEF FUND (HEERF) ARE PAID DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS.

The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act was enacted into law on March 27, 2020 as a $2 Trillion national economic rescue package. Approximately $14B of the funding was reserved for higher education institutions and the students they serve through the Higher Education Emergency Relief Fund (HEERF). Siena College awarded $159,442 in aid to students through this fund during the year ending May 31, 2020.
SCHOLARSHIPS TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS WHO MEET THE CRITERIA OF THE COLLEGE OR TRUST INSTRUMENT WHO ESTABLISHED THE SCHOLARSHIP FUND.

The Chicago School of Professional Psychology provides institutional aid in the form of scholarships, fellowships, and grants to new and continuing students. The awarding of institutional aid depends on factors such as recommendations, academic standing, and other criteria related to admission or participation in a program. The Chicago School maintains records of institutional aid awards, criteria for awarding institutional aid, and evidence of the criteria for institutional aid being met by recipients.

FINANCIAL AID IS CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS TO COVER ANY OUTSTANDING INSTITUTIONAL CHARGES. ANY CREDIT BALANCE IS REFUNDED TO THE STUDENT TO BE USED FOR OTHER EDUCATIONAL-RELATED EXPENSES. STUDENTS RECEIVING FEDERAL AND/OR STATE AID MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). BY SIGNING THE FAFSA, THE STUDENT AGREES THAT HE OR SHE "WILL USE FEDERAL AND/OR STATE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID ONLY TO PAY THE COST OF ATTENDING AN INSTITUTION OF HIGHER EDUCATION."

NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WITH DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED. RECIPIENTS OF NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS MUST COMPLETE A FAFSA APPLICATION, BE US CITIZENS OR ELIGIBLE NON-CITIZENS, BE ENROLLED IN A DEGREE OR CERTIFICATE PROGRAM, AND BE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS.
ALL GRANTS ARE INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID AND APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT BY KANSAS CITY ART INSTITUTE.

The organization provides grants/contributions to other organizations which are tax-exempt under IRC Section 501(c)(3) and governmental divisions that benefit the community and region through programs and activities.
CWS awards are allocated back to wages as required by IPEDs reporting.

FOR FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID GRANTS, INDIVIDUAL FAFSA AND PERSONAL TAX RETURNS ARE VERIFIED FOR RECIPIENT ELIGIBILITY. SEVERAL LAYERS OF SUPERVISORY APPROVALS ARE BUILT INTO THE INTERNAL FINANCIAL AID PROCESS. FOR OTHER FEDERALLY FUNDED GRANTS (NIH, ETC.), ACTIVITY IS ADMINISTERED BY A DEDICATED EMPLOYEE, SUBJECT TO SEVERAL LAYERS OF SUPERVISORY REVIEW AND APPROVAL. PAYROLL COSTS AND OTHER ALLOCATED EXPENDITURES ARE DOCUMENTED AND REVIEWED BY THE FINANCE DEPT. AS WELL AT EXTERNAL AUDITORS.

NEUMANN UNIVERSITY'S PROCESS FOR MONITORING FINANCIAL AID AND MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IS A COMBINATION OF PROCEDURES INVOLVING THE FOLLOWING OFFICES; FINANCIAL AID, INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT, REGISTRAR, AND THE BUSINESS OFFICE. INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARD SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ACCORDING TO THE SPECIFICATIONS/REQUIREMENTS OF THE SPECIFIC AWARD.
